div.p: A POSTHUME of RICHARD BROME, An Ingenious Servant, and Imitator of his Master, that famously Renowned Poet Ben Johnson.

quote.p:
Aut prodesse solent, aut delectare Poetae.
Dramatis Personae.

div.p: LONDON, Printed for Andrew Crook, and are to be sold at the Green Dragon in St. Pauls Church-yard: And Henry Broom at the Gun in Ivy-lane. 1658.

div.head: Upon AGLAƲRA printed in Folio.
div.l: By this large Margent did the Poet mean
To have a Comment writ upon his Scene?
Or is it that the Ladies, who ne're look
On any but a Poeme or Play-book,
May, in each page, have space to scribble down
When such a Lord, or Fashion comes to Town.
As Swaines in Almanacks account do keep,
When their Cow calv'd, and when they bought their sheep?
Ink is the life of Paper: 'tis meet then,
That this which scap'd the Press should feel the Pen.
A Room with one side furnish'd, or a face
Painted half-way, is but a faire disgrace.
This great voluminous Pamphlet may be said
To be like one that hath more haire then head;
More excrement then body. Trees, which sprout
With broadest leaves, have still the smallest fruit.
When I saw so much white, I did begin
To think Aglaura either did lie in,
Or else took Pennance. Never did I see
(unlesse in Bills dasht In the Chancerie).
So little in so much; as if the feet
Of Poetry, like Law, were sold by th'sheet.
If this new fashion should but last one yeare,
Poets, as Clerks, would make our paper dear.
Doth not the Artist erre, and blast his fame
That sets out pictures lesser then the frame?
Was ever Chamberlaine so mad, to dare
To lodge a childe in the great Bed at Ware?
Aglaura would please better, did she lie
I'th' narrow bounds of an Epitomie.
Pieces that are weav'd of the finest twist,
(As Silk and Plush) have still more stuffe then list.
She, that in Persian habit made great brags,
Degenerates in this excesse of rags;
Who, by her Giant-bulk this only gaines,
Perchance in Libraries to hang in chaines.
Tis not in Book, as Cloth; we never say
Make London-measure, when we buy a Play:
But rather have them pair'd: Those leaves be faire
To the judicious, which more spotted are.
Give me the sociable Pocket-books.
These empty Folio's only please the Cooks.

div.head: A SONG.
div.l: A Way with all grief and give us more sack.
'Tis that which we love, let love have no lack.
Nor sorrow, nor care can crosse our delights,
Nor witches, nor goblins, nor Buttery sprights,
Tho' the candles burne dimme while we can do thus,
We'll scorn to flie them: but we'll make them flie us.
Old Sack, and old Songs, and a merry old crew
Will fright away Sprights, when the ground looks blew.

div.head: A PROLOGUE.
div.l: HE that could never boast, nor seek the way,
To prepare friends to magnifie his Play,
Nor raile at's Auditory for unjust,
If they not lik't it nor was so mistrust.
Ful ever in himself, that he besought
Preapprobation though they lik't it not.
Nor ever had the luck to have his name
Clap't up above this merit. Nor the shame
To be cried down below it. He this night
Your faire and free Attention does invite.
Only he prays no prejudice be brought
By any that before-hand wish it nought.
And that ye all be pleas'd to heare and see,
With Candor suiting his Integritie.
That for the Writer. Something we must say,
Now in defence of us, and of the Play
We shall present no Scandal or Abuse,
To vertue or to honour. Nor traduce
Person of worth. Nor point at the disgrace
Of any one residing in the Place,
On which our Scene is laid, nor any Action shew,
Of thing has there been done, for ought we know.
Though it be probable that such have been.
But if some vicious persons be brought in.
As no new Buildings, nor the strongest hold
Can keep out Rats and Vermine bad and bold.
Let not the sight of such be ill endur'd;
All sores are seen and search't before th' are cur'd.
As Ruffian, Bawd, and the licentious crew,
Too apt to pester Scituations new.

div.head: Another Prologue.
div.l: 'Tis not amisse ere we begin our Play,
T' intreat you, that you take the same surveigh
Into your fancie, as our Poet took,
Of Covent-Garden, when he wrote his Book.
Some ten years since, when it was grown with weeds.
Not set, as now it is, with Noble Seeds.
Which make the Garden glorious. And much
Our Poet craves and hopes you will not grutch
It him, that since so happily his Pen
Foretold its faire emprovement, and that men
Of worth and honour should renown the place.
The Play may still retain its former grace.

div.head: To my LORD of Newcastle, on his PLAY called THE VARIETY. He having commanded to give him my true opinion of it.
div.l: I Could not think these seven yeares, but that I
In part a Poet was, and so might lie,
By the Poetick Licence. But I finde
Now I am none, and strictly am confin'd
To truth, if therefore I subpaena'd were
Before the Court of Chancerie to swear.
Or if from thence I should be higher sent,
And on my life unto a Parliament
Of wit and judgement, there to certifie
What I could say of your VARIETY:
I would depose each Scene appear'd to me
An Act of wit, each Act a Comedy,
And all was such, to all that understood,
As knowing Johnson, swore By God 'twas good.

list.item: Rooksbill, a great Builder in Covent-Garden.
Crossewill, a Countrey Gentleman, Lodger in his Buildings.
Cockbrain, a Justice of Peace, the Weeder of the Garden.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I Marry Sir! This is something like! These appear like Buildings! Here's Architecture exprest indeed! It is a most sightly scituation, and fit for Gentry and Nobility.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: When it is all finished, doubtlesse it will be handsome.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
It will be glorious: and yond magnificent Peece, the Piazzo, will excel that at Venice, by hearsay, (I ne're travell'd). A hearty blessing on their braines, honours, and wealths, that are Projectors, Furtherers, and Performers of such great works. And now I come to you Mr. Rookesbill: I like your Rowe of houses most incomparably. Your money never
shone so on your Counting-boards, as in those Structures.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I have pil'd up a Leash of thousand pounds in walls and windows there.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: It will all come again with large encrease.

And better is your money thus let out on red and white, then upon black and white, I say. You cannot think how I am taken with that Rowe! How even and straight they are! And so are all indeed. The Surveyor( what e're he was) has manifested himself the Master of his great Art. How he has wedded strength to beauty; state to uniformity; commodiousnesse with perspicuity! All, all as't should be!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: If all were as well tenanted and inhabited by worthy persons.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Phew; that will follow. What new Plantation was ever peopled with the better sort at first; nay, commonly, the lewdest blades, and naughtypacks are either necessitated to 'hem, or else do prove the most forward venturers. Is not lime and hair the first in all your foundations? do we not soile or dung our lands, before we sowe or plant any thing that's good in 'hem? And do not weeds creep up first in all Gardens? and why not then in this? which never was a Garden until now; and which will be the Garden of Gardens, I foresee't. And for the weeds in it, let me alone for the weeding of them out. And so as my Reverend Ancestor Justice Adam Overdoe, was wont to say, In Heavens name and the Kings, and for the good of the Common-wealth I will go about it.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p:
I would a few more of the Worshipful hereabouts, (whether they be in Commission or not) were as well minded that way as you are Sir; we should
then have all sweet and clean, and that quickly too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I have thought upon a way for't, Mr. Rooksbill: and I will pursue it, viz. to finde out all the enormities, yet be my selfe unspied: whereby I will tread out the spark of impiety, whilest it is yet a spark and not a flame; and break the egge of a mischief, whilest it is yet an egge and not a Cockatrice. Then doubt not of worthy tenants for your houses Mr. Rooksbill.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, your best furtherance.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I had a letter bur last night from a worthy friend, a West-countrey Gentleman, that is, now coming up with his family to live in Town here; and desire is to inhabit in these buildings. He was to lie at Hammersmith last night, and requested an early meeting of me this morning here, to assist him in the taking of a house. It is my businesse hither; for he could never do't himselfe. He has the oldest touchy, wrangling humour.— But in a harmlesse way; for he hurts no body, and pleases himself in it. His children have all the trouble of it, that do anger him in obeying him sometimes. You will know him anon. I mean, he shall be your Tenant. And luckily he comes.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It is not enough you tell me of obedience. Or that you are obedient. But I will be obeyed in my own way. Do you see—

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: My noble friend Mr. Croswill, right happily met.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Your troublesome friend Mr. Cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
No trouble at all, Sir, though I have prevented
yours in finding a fit house for you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: You ha' not ha' you, ha?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Actum est Mr. Croswill. But Civility pardon me, Is not this your daughter?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: All the Shee-things I have: and would I were well rid of her too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs. Katherine, Welcome— Mr. Gabriel, I take it.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Gabriel Croswill is my name.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: But where's your younger sonne Mihill? There's a spark!

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: A Spark! A dunce I fear by this time like his brother Sheepshead there.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Gabriel is my proper name.

sp.speaker: Gros.
sp.p: I have not seen him this Twelve-moneth, since I chamber'd him a Student here in Town.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: In town, and I not know it?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: He knows not yet of my coming neither, nor shall not, till I steal upon him; and if I finde him mopish like his brother, I know what I will doe.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Have you not heard from him lately?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Yes, often by his letters, lesse I could reade more comfort in 'hem. I fear he's turn'd Precisian, for all his Epistles end with Amen; and the-matter of 'hem is such as if he could teach me to ask him blessing.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: A comfortable hearing of a young man.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Is it so Sir? but I'le new mould him if it be so.— I'le tell you Mr. Cockbrayne; never was such a father so crost in his children. They will not obey me in my way. I grant, they do things that other fathers would rejoyce at. But I will be obeyed in my own way, dee see. Here's my eldest sonne. Mark how he stands, as if he had learn't a posture at Knights-bridge
spittle as we came along while-eare. He was not only borne without wit, but with an obstinate resolution, never to have any. I mean, such wit as might become a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Was that resolution borne in him think you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It could never grow up in him still as it does else. When I would have him take his horse, and follow the dogs, and associate Gentlemen, in hawking, hunting, or such like exercises, he'l run you a foot five mile another way, to meet the brethren of the separation, at such exercises as I never sent him to (I am sure) on worky dayes. And whereas most Gentlemen run into other mens books, in hands that they care not who reades, he has a book of his own Short-writing in his pocket, of such stuffe as is fit for no mans reading indeed but his own.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surely Sir.—

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Sure you are an Asse. Hold your tongue.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You are my father.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: What comfort should I have, were my son such.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: And he has nothing but hang'd the head, as you see now, ever since Holiday sports were cried up in the Countrey. And but for that, and to talk with some of the silenc'd Pastors here in town about it, I should not have drawn him up.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I would I could change a sonne w' you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What kinde of thing is thy sonne? ha! dost thou look like one that could have a sonne fit for me to father, ha? And yet the best take both, and t' please you at all adventures, ha?

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I am sure there cannot be a worse, or more debauch'd reprobate then mine is living.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
And is the devil too good a Master for
him, think'st thou, ha? Wherein can I deserve so ill at thy hands, fellow, whate're thou art, that thou should'st wish me comber'd with a worse burden, when thou hearest me complain of this, ha? What is this fellow that you dare know him, Friend Cockbrayn? I will not dwell within three parishes of him.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: My tenant! Blesse me from him. I had rather all my Rents were Bawdy houses.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Think nothing of his words, he'll forget all instantly. The best natur'd man living.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Dost thou stand like a son now that hears his father abus'd, ha?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I am praying for the conversion of the young man he speaks of.

sp.speaker: Coek.
sp.p: Well said, Mr. Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But by the way, where's your sonne Anthony? have you not heard of him yet?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Never since he forsook me, on the discontent he took, in that he might not marry your daughter there. And where he lives, or whether he lives or not, I know not. I hope your davghter is a comfort to you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Yes, in keeping her chamber whole weeks together, sullening upon her Samplery breech-work, when I was in hope she would have made me a Grandfather ere now. But she has a humour, forsooth, since we put your son by her, to make me a match-broker, her marriage-Maker; when I tell you friend, there has been so many untoward matches of Parents making, that I have sworn she shall make her own choice, though it be of one I hate. Make me her match-maker! Must I obey her, or she me, ha?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I wish, with teares, my sonne had had her now.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Wherein Sir, (under correction do I disobey you?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: In that very word, under correction, thou disobey'st me. Are you to be under correction at these yeares? ha! If I ha' not already taught you manners beyond the help of correction, go, seek a wiser father to mend 'hem.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Yet give me leave, dear Sir, in my excuse.—

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Leave out correction then.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: If I were forward as many Maidens are,
To wish a husband, must I not be sought?
I never was a Gadder: and my Mother,
Before she dy'd, adjur'd me to be none.
I hope you'll give me leave to keep your house.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: La there again! How subtly she seeks dominion over me! No, huswife, No; you keep no house of mine. I'll nestle you no longer under my wing. Are you not fledge; I'll have you fly out I, as other mens daughters do; and keep a house of your own if you can find it.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: We had a kinswoman flew out too lately, I take it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What tell'st thou me of her; wise-acres? Can they not flie out a little, but they must turne arrant whores, ha? Tell me of your kinswoman? 'Tis true, she was my Neece; she went to't a little afore her time? some two years since, and so fled from Religion; and is turn'd Turk, we fear. And what of that in your precisiancial wisdom? I have such children as no man has. But (as I was saying,) would ye top me huswife, ha! Look you, now I chide her, she sayes nothing. Is this obedience, ha?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Perhaps, I might unfortunately cast my affection on a man that would refuse me.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: That man I would desire to know; shew me that man; see if I swinge him not dares slight my daughter.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Still the old humour, self-will'd, crosse, and touchie; but suddainly reconcil'd. Come, Mr. Croswil, to the businesse.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Oh, you told me of a house you had found for me.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Yes Sir. And here's the Landlord.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Does he look, or go like one could let a house worthy of me.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Sir, we have able Builders here, that will not carry least shew of their buildings on their backs. This is a rich sufficient man, I assure you, and my friend.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I cry him heartily mercy, and embrace him. And now I note you better, you look like Thrift it self.
sp.stage: Enter Dorcas above upon a Bellconie. Gabriel gazes at her. Dorcas is habited like a Curtizan of Venice.
sp.p: I cannot think you will throw away your houses at a cast. You have a sonne, perhaps, that may, by the commendations you gave of him. Lets see your house.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Come away Mr. Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Come Sir, what do you gape and shake the head at there? I'll lay my life he has spied the little Crosse upon the new Church yond, and is at defiance with it. Sirrah, I will make you honour the first syllable of my name. My name is Will. Croswill, and I will have my humour. Let those that talk of me for it, speak their pleasure, I will do mine.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I shall obey you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Now you are in the right. You shall indeed. I'll make your heart ake else, dee see.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
But truly I was looking at that Image; that
painted idolatrous image yonder, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O heresie! It is some Lady, or Gentlewoman standing upon her Bellconey.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Her Bellconey? Where is it? I can spy from her foot to her face, yet I can see no Bellconey she has.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What a Knave's this: That's the Bellconey she stands on, that which jets out so on the forepart of the house; every house here has one of 'hem.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: 'Tis very good; I like the jetting out of the forepart very well; it is a gallant fashion indeed.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I guess what she is, what ere I have said. O Justice look to thine office.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Come now to this house, and then to my son Mihil, the Spark you spoke of. And if I find him cross too, I'le cross him: Let him look to't. dee see.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I'le see you hous'd; and then about my project, which is for weeding of this hopeful Garden. Ex. omnes.
sp.stage: Gabriel stayes last looking up at her.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Why should not we in England use that freedome
The famous Curtezans have in Italy:
We have the art, and know the Theory
To allure and catch the wandring eyes of Lovers;
Yea, and their hearts too: but our stricter Lawes
Forbids the publique practise, our desires
Are high as theirs; our wills as apt and forward;
Our wits as ripe, our beauties more attractive;
Or Travellers are shrewd lyars. Where's the let?
Only in bashful coward custome, that
Stoops i'the shoulders, and submits the neck
To bondage of Authority; to these Lawes,
That men of feeble age and weaker eye-sight
Have fram'd to bar their sons from youthful pleasures.
Possets and Cawdels on their queasie stomacks,
Whilst I fly out in brave rebellion;
And offer, at the least, to break these shackles
That holds our legs together: And begin
A fashion, which pursu'd by Cyprian Dames,
May perswade Justice to allow our Games.
Who knows? I'le try. Francisca bring my Lute.
sp.stage: while she is tuning her Lute: Enter Nich. Rookesbill, Anthony in a false beard, Clotpoll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Troth I have a great mind to be one of the Philoblathici, a Brother of the Blade and Battoon, as you translate it; now ye have beat it into my head: But I fear I shall never come on and off handsomely. I have mettal enough methinks, but I know not how methinks to put it out.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: We'l help you out with it, and set it flying for you never doubt it.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Obotts, you mean my money mettal, I mean my valour mettal I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Peace, heark.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: T'other flyes fast enough already.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Pox on ye peace.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O most melodious.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Most odious, Did you say? It is methinks most odoriferous.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What new devise can this be? Look!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: She is vanisht. Is't not the Mountebanks Wife that was here; and now come again to play some new merry tricks by herself.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A botts on't, I never saw that Mountebank; they say, he brought the first resort into this new plantation, and sow'd so much seed of Knavery and Cozenage here, that 'tis fear'd 'twill never out.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay but this creature: What can she be?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And then again, he drew such flocks of idle people to him, that the Players, they say, curst him abhominably.

sp.speaker: Ant,
sp.p: Thou ever talk'st of the wrong matter.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Cry mercy Brothers of the Blade and Battoune: Do you think if I give my endeavour to it, I shall ever learn to roar and carry it as you do, that have it naturally, as you say.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes, as we'll beat it into you. But this woman, this musical woman, that set her self out to show so, I would be satisfied in her.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And she be as able as she seems, she has in her to satisfie you, and you were a Brother of ten Blades, and ten Battounes.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow— Peace. I'le battoune thy teeth into thy tongue else; she bears a stately presence. Thou never saw'st her before: Didst thou Toney?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No; but I heard an inkling at the Paris Tavern last night of a She-Gallant-that had travelled France and Italy; and that she would—

sp.speaker: (Clot.
sp.p: Battoun thy teeth into thy tongue.)

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Plant some of her forraign collections, the fruits of her travels, in this Garden here, to try how they would grow or thrive on English earth.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Young Pig was speaking of such a one to me, and that she was a Mumper.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: What's that a Sister of the Scabberd, brother of the Blade?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come, come; we'l in, we'l in; 'tis one of our fathers buildings; I'le see the Inhabitants. Some money Clot. furnish I say, and quickly.— I vow—

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You shall, you shall.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What shall I?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Vow twice before you have it.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow, and I vow again, I'le coyn thy brains.—

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Hold, hold, take your powl money; I thought I would have my will; and the word I look-for, I'le coyn thy brains.—

I do not love to give my money for nothing, I have a volume of words here, the worst of 'hem is as good as a blow; and then I save my Crown whole half a dozen times a day, by half a crown a time, there's half in half sav'd by that.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come let's appear civil, till we have our entrance, and then as occasion serves—
Who would you speak withal?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Your Mistress, little one.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Do you know her Sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No; but I would know her, that's the business: I mean the musical Gentlewoman that was fidling, and so many in the What-doe-call't een now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: What-doe-call her Sir, I pray?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What-doe-call her; 'tis not come to that yet, prethee let me see and speak with her first.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You are dispos'd I think.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What should we do here else?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: You wont thrust in upon a body whether one will or no.

sp.speaker: Ant. Nic.
sp.p: Away you Monkey.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: O me, What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O my brave Philoblathici.—

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What's the matter the Girl cryes out so?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I know not: I fear some rude company, some of the wild crew are broke into the house.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Within. Whether would you go, you wont rob the house will ye?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Will ye be quiet Whiskin?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O me 'tis so: Hell's broke loose; this comes of your new fingle-fangle fashion, your prepostrous Italian way forsooth: would I could have kept my old way of pots and pipes, and my Strong-water course for customers: The very first twang of your fiddle guts has broke all, and conjur'd a legion of devils among us.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Nay, there's but a Leash of us. How now?
Who have we here? Are these the far travel'd Ladies?
O thou party perpale, or rather parboild Bawd.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What shall I do? Dam. Out alass; sure they are devils indeed.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Art thou travel'd cross the Seas from the Bankside hither, old Countess of Codpiece-row?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Party perpale and parboild Bawd.—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And is this the Damsel that has been in France and Italy? Clot. Codpiece-row.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Peace ye roaring Scabs: I'le be sworn she supt at Paris Tavern last night, and lay not long ago at the Venice by Whitefryers Dock.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Prethee what is she Madge?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: A civil Gentlewoman you see she is.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: She has none of the best faces: but is she warrantable; I have not had a civil night these three moneths.

sp.speaker: Madge.
sp.p: Nor none are like to have here, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O Madge how I do long thy thing to ding didle ding.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: O Nick, I am not in the humour, no more is she to be o'the merry pin now; I am sure her case is too lamentable. But if you will all sit down, I'le give you a bottle of wine, and we'l relate her story to you, so you will be civil. Nic Well for once, I care not if we be.
sp.stage: A Table bottle, light, and Tobacco stales.
sp.p: Let us set to't then; sit down brother Toney, sit down Gentlewoman, we shall know your name anon, I hope it will fall in your story; sit down Clotpoll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You will call me brother Clotpoll too when I have taken my oath, and paid my entrance into the faternity of the Blade and the Battoun.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: 'Tis like we shall. Now Lady of the Stygian Lake, thou black infernal Madge, begin the dismal story, whilst I begin the bottle.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: This Gentlewoman whose name is Damyris.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Damyris stay. Her nick-name then is Dammy, so we may call her when we grow familiar: and to begin that familiarity, Dammy here's to you.— drink.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And what's your nick-name I pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nick: only Nick, Madge there knows it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Then I believe your name is Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow-witty. Yes Dammy, and my Sirname is Rookesbill, and so is my Fathers too: and what do you make o'that?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Nothing not I Sir: sure this is he.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: And I would he were nothing, so I had all he has: I must have tother glass to wash him out of my mouth, he furs it worse then Mondongas Tobacco. Here old Madge, and to all the birds that shall wonder at thy howletship, when thou rid'st in an Ivy-bush, call'd a Cart.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Well mad Nick, I'le pledge thee in hope to see as many flutter about the tree, that thou shalt clime backwards.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A pox thou wilt be stifled with Offal and Carret leaves before that day.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fie, fie, what talk's this? 'tis he I am consident.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: These are our ordinary complements, we wish no harm.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No Dammy I vow, not I to any breathing.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But your Father Nick.— Is he that Rookesbill.—

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: But my Fathet; Pox rot ye, why do ye put me in mind of him again, he sticks i'my throat, now I'le wash him a little further.— Here Brother Toney

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Gramercy Brother Nick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And to all the brothers that are, and are to be of the Blade and the Battoun.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: There said you well Clotpoll: Here 'tis—

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I would but have asked you whether your Father were that Rookesbill that is call'd the great Builder.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p:
Yes marry is it he forsooth; he has built I know not how many houses hereabout, though he goes Dammy as if he were not worth a groat; and all his cloaths I vow are not worth this hilt, except those he wears, and prayes for fair weather in, on my Lord Mayors Day; and you are his Tenant, though perhaps you know it not, and may be mine; therefore use me well: for this house and the rest I hope will be mine, as well as I can hope he is mortal, of which I must confess I have been in some doubt, though now I hope again, he will be the first shall lay his bones i'the new Church, though the Church-yard be too good
for him before 'tis consecrated. So give me the to-the cup, for now he offends my stomack. Here's to thee now Clotpoll.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And to all the Sisters of the Scabberd Brother in Election. dee hear, Pray talk of his father no more, for the next brings him to the belly-work, and then he'll drink him quite through him.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And so we shall have a foul house.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No he shall stick there. Now to the story Gentlewoman, 'twas that we sate for.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I to the story, I vow I had almost forgot it; and I am the worst at Sack in a morning: Dear Dammy to the story.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Good Sir my heart's too full to utter't.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Troth and my head's too full to hear it: But I'le go out and quarrel with some body to settle my brains, then go down to Mich Crossewill to put him in mind of our meeting to day; then if you will meet me at the Goat at Dinner, wee'll have it all at large.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Will you be there indeed Sir, I would speak with you seriously.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Dammy if I be not, may my father out live me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We both here promise you he shall be there by noon.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: 'Lady, 'tis sworn by Blade and by Battoun.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: This will be the bravest discovery for Mihill, the new Italian Bona Roba Catsoe.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Why so sad on the suddain Niece.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: But do you think hee'll come as he has promis'd.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: He never breaks a promise with any of us 'though he fail all the honest part o'the world: But I trust you are not taken with the Ruffian, you'll nere get penny by him.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I prethee peace, I care not.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But Mystris, rhere is a Gallant now below, a Gingle boy indeed, that has his pockets full of, crowns that chide for vent. Shall I call him up to you.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I will see no man.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: How's that? I hope you jest.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Indeed, I hope you jest.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: You will not hinder the house, I hope. Marry heigh. This were a humour and 'twould last. Go fetch him up.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'le flie then out at window. Nay, by this steel 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What's the matter? have I got a mad woman into the house. What do you go about to break me the first day of your coming, before you have hansell'd a Couch or a Bedside in't. Were you but now all o'th heigh to set your self out for a signe with your fiddle cum twang, and promise such wonders, forsooth, and will not now be seen. Pray what's the Riddle.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'll tell thee all anon. Prithie excuse me. I know thy share of his sins bounty would not come to thus much, take it, I give it thee. And prithee let me be honest till I have a mince to be otherwise, and I'le hinder thee nothing.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Well, I'le dismisse the Gallant, and send you, Sirrah, for another wench. I'le have Besse Bufflehead again. This kicksy wincy wincy Giddibrain will spoil all I'le no more Italian tricks.—
sp.l: Thus some have by the phrensie of despair
Fumously run into the sea to throw
Their wretched bodies, but when come near
They saw the billows rise, heard Boreas blow,
And horrid death appearing on the Maine,
A sudden fear hath sent them back again.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: NAy, but honest Shoomaker; thy honest price.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I tell you intruth, Sir, 'tis as good a boot as ever you pull'd on in your life.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A little too streight, I doubt. What do you think o' my boots honest Tailor.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: They do exceeding handsomely, never trust me Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Never fear it Tailor, you shall trust me, and please you.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: You are pleasant Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And what do you think of my suite Shoomaker? can you say as much for the Tailor as he for you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: A very neat suite, Sir, and becomes you excellent.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Honest men both, and hold together; one would little think you were so near neighbours. Well, you, have fitted me both, I must confesse. But how I shall fit you, now there's the point.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: There's but one way for than and please you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: With paying us our money Sit.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Still both in a tale, I can not but commend your neighbourhood, I muse my Laundresse stayes,
I sent her three or foure wayes for moneys. But do not you stay for that. I have wayes enough to pay you. I have ploughes a going that you dream not of.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir, we dream of nothing but ready money, sleeping or waking.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I shall be rich enough ne're fear't. I have a venter in the new soap businesse man.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: We are but servants, Sir. And our Masters themselves have no faith, in slippery projects.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: Besides, the women begin to grumble against that slippery project shrewdly, and, 'tis feard, will mutinie shortly.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Burlakin, and they may prove more troublesome then a commotion of Sailors.
O welcome, Laundresse, where's the money.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: Not a penny of money, Sir, can I get. But here's one come to town has brought you enough, and you can have grace to finger it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Who's that I prithee.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: Your father, your father Sir. I met his man by great chance, who told me his Master meanes to steal upon you presently, and take you as he findes you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Is he come up with his crosse tricks. I heard he was to come. And that he meanes to live here altogether. He has had an aime these dozen years to live in town here, but never was fully bent on't until the Proclamation of restraint spurr'd him up. 'Tis such a Crossewill. Well, he is my father, and I am utterly undone if thou help'st me not now at a pinch, at a pinch, dear Laundresse. Go borrow me a Gown,
and some foure or five Law-books? for, I protest, mine are in Duck-lane. Nay, trudge, sweet Laundresse, trudge.— Ex. Laun. Honest Tailor and Shoemaker convey your selves away quietly, and I'll pay you to morrow, as I am a Gentleman:

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: As I am a Shoemaker, and that's a kinde of a Gentleman, you know, I'll not stirre till I have my money, I am not an Asse Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: No body sayes thou art.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: I have had too many such tricks put upon me i' my dayes.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A trick! as I hope for money it is no trick.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: Well Sir, trick or no trick. I must have my money or my boots, and that's plain dealing.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: A pox o'th' boots, so my legs were out of 'hem. Would they were i'thy throat, spurres and all, you will not out.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: No marry will we not.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Well-said Shoomaker, I commend thee, thou hast a better heart then I, though my stomack's good.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: O well said, my good Laundresse. How am I bound to thee; yet all this wo'not do't Laundresse. Thou must bestir thy stumps a little further, and borrow me a couple of Gownes more for these Rascals here that will not away.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: How! wo'not away? And they were well serv'd, they would be thrust out of doors for saucie companions. Your Masters would not put a Gentleman to his trumps thus.

sp.speaker: M;.
sp.p:
Nay, sweet Laundresse, restrain thy tongue, and stretch thy feet. A couple of Gowns, good
Laundresse, and forget not caps. Ex. If I do now furnish you like Civil Lawyers, and you do not keep your countenances; if ever you do but peep in at the Hall-door at Christmas to see the revels, I'le have you set i'th' stocks for this beleeve it.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: If you do, Sir, I may hap be even with you before the year comes about, and set you in our stocks for't.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: But will you make Lawyers of us.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Have you a minde to have your money you unbelieving Rascals.

sp.speaker: Shoc.
sp.p: I see your drift, and hope you'll prove an honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thou hast some hope, though no faith nor trust in any man.

sp.speaker: Shoe.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, our Masters sit at great rents, and keep great families.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, they are remov'd into the new plantation here, where, they say, are a tribe of Infidel-tradesmen, that have made a Law within your selves to put no trust in Gentlemen. But beare your selves handsomely here you were best. I am acquainted with a crew that haunts about your habitations, with whom I will joyne, and so batter your windows one of these nights else.— O welcom, Laundresse, how doest thou toile for me.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: Your fathers talking, as I am a woman, below.— As thou art a woman below, well-said. Come on with these Gownes, and lets see how yow'll look. If we had time, the Shoomaker should wash his face; but seeing there is no remedy; pull the cap in your eyes, and good enongh. Now Laundresse, set us stooles, and leave us.

sp.speaker: Laun.
sp.p: I hear him coming up.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Now let him come, we are ready for him. Shoomaker, keep your hand underneath the
book, that the pitch do not discover you.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I warrant you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And Taylor, be sure you have no Needle on your sleeve, nor thread about your neck.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I warrant you too for me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi:
sp.p: He's enrred.
sp.stage: Enter Croswill, Belt, and stand aside.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Remitter, I say, is where a man hath two titles, that is to say, one of an elder, the other of a later. And he cometh to the land by the later title; yet the Law adjudgeth him to be in by the force of the elder title. If the tenant in the taile discontinue the taile, and after he diseaseth his discontinue, and so dieth seised, whereby the tenants descend to their issue, as to his Cousin inheritable by force of the taile. In this case the tenants descend, who have right by force of the taile, a Remitter in the taile taken for that in the Law, shall put and adjudge him to be in by force of descent. Pox on ye, speak something good or bad, somewhat.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: The Remitter, you say, is seised i'th' tail.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Excellent Shoomaker, I say so, and again, I say, that if the tenant in the taile in feoffe his son, or his Cousin, inheritable by force of the taile, the which sonne or cousin at the time of the feoffment is within age, and after the tenant in the taile dierh, this is a Remitter to the heire in the taile to whom the feoffment is made, now Taylor.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Think you so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Look either Fitzherbert, Perkins, or Dier, and you shall finde it in the second part of Richard Cordelyon. So much for Remitter. Now I'll put a plain home-spun case, as a man may say, which we call a moot-case.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: I pray do Sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Some father might take joy of such a sonne now. This takes not me. No, this is not my way.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: The case is this
pull up your grounds closer and be hang'd, you are a Tailor, and you: a Shoomaker.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: And you owe us money.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I put the case, I do, to you for a suit of clothes.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And to you for a paire of boots.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I have broke my day with you both. Suppose so.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Very well, we do.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You clap a Sergeant o' my back. I put in bail, remove it, and carry it up into the upper Court, with habeas-Corpus; bring it down again into the lower Court with procedendo; then take it from thence, and bring it into the Chancery with a Certiorari; I; and if you look not to it, bring it out of the Chancery again, and thus will I keep you from your money till your suite and your boots be worne out before you recover penny of me.

sp.speaker: Sho.
sp.p: S'ly'd but you shall not, your father shall know all first.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: S'foot Shoomaker wilt thou be an Asse. I do but put a case, Have you not seen it tried.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Yes, very often.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p:
Away with books. Away with Law. Away with madnesse. I, God blesse thee, and make thee his servant, and defend thee from Law, I say. Take up these books, sarrah, and carry them presently into Pauls Church-yard dee see, and change them all for Histories, as pleasant as profitable; Arthur of Britain,
Primalion of Greece, Amadis of Gaul, and such like de see.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope he do's but jest.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: And do you heare, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Get Bells work, and you can, into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Which Bell, Sir? Adam Bell, with Clim o'th' 'Clough, and William of Cloudesley.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Adam Bell you Asse? Valiant Bell that kill'd the Dragon.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: You mean St. George.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Sir Jolthead, do I not. I'le teach you to chop logick, with me.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Sfoot, how shall I answer my borrow'd books? Stay Belt. Pray Sir, do not change my books.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, I will change them and you too: Did I leave thee here to learn fashions and manners, that thou mightst carry thy self like a Gentleman, and dost thou wast thy brains in learning a language that I understand not a word of? ha! I had been as good have brought thee up among the wild Irish.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Why alass Sir, Had I not better keep my self within my Chamber, at my Studie, then be rioting abroad, wasting both money and time, which is more precious then money? if you did know the inconvenience of company, you would rather incourage and commend my retir'd life, then any wayes dehort me from it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why Sir did not I keep companie think you when I was young? Ha!

sp.speaker: Ml.
sp.p: Yes Sir; but the times are much alter'd, and youth more corrupted now, they did not drink and wench in those dayes, but nay, o 'tis abominable in these.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Why this is that I fear'd, the boyes turning
meacock too, after his elder brother, 'twas time to look to him.

sp.speaker: Nich.
sp.p: Why Croswill Mich What, not up yet and be hang'd. Or ha ye a wench a bed wye. Is this keeping your home. Mihil runs to the door and holds it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Sfoot the Rogue Rooksbil and his crew, I fear'd as much.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Break open the door, let me come to't.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Forbear, or be hang'd, you will undo me, my father's here. I'll meet you anon as I am honest.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Your father's a Clowterdepouch. Nay, I will come then, what Madamoiselle do you call father.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You would not believe me. Pray be civil.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis so, we will Cry mercy, you are busie, we will not moote to day then?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope you may excuse me, I'le be w'ye anon.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come to the Goat Capricorne. We have the bravest new discovery.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: How now! what are these?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: They are Gentlemen of my standing, Sir, that have a little over-studied themselves, and are somewhat—.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Mad; are they not? And so will you be shortly, if you follow these courses. Mooting do they call it? you shall moote nor mute here no longer. Therefore on with your cloak and sword, follow me to the Tavern and leave me such long-tail'd company as these are, for I do not like them.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: No more do I, Sir, if I knew how to be rid of 'hem.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I think thou hast ne're a sword, hast thou, ha?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Where is it, Sir, let me se't Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: 'Tis here, under my bed, Sir.— Reach it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why there's a Lawyers trick right, make his weapon companion with his Pisse-pot. Fie, fie, here's a tool indeed. There's money, Sir, buy you a good one, one with the Mathematical hilt as they terme it.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: It would do better in Mathematical books. Sir, offer me no money, pray Sir, but for books.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Go to, you are a peevish Jack, do not provoke me: do not you owe me obedience? ha!

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: 'Tis good you do. Well, take that money; and put your selfe into cloathes befitting your rank, Do so. And let me see you, squirting about without a weapon, like an Attorneys Clerk in Tearm-time, and I'l weapon you, What, shall I have a Noddie of you. This frets him to the liver. Go to, never hang the head for the matter. For I tell thee I will have it so, and herein be knowen what I am.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You are known sufficiently for your crosse humour already; in which I'll try you if I can make you double this money, for this will not serve my turne.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What have you told it after me, you had best weigh it too.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: No Sir, but I have computed that for my present use, here is too much by halfe, pray Sir, take halfe back.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Bodie o' me, what a perverse knave is this, to crosse me thus! Is there too much, say you? ha.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes truly, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Let me see't. Go thy wayes, take thy musty books, and rhy rustie whittle here again. And take your foolish plodding dunci-coxcomely course, till I look after you again. Come away sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Sfoot, who's the Gull now? Taylor, Shoomaker, you may go pawn your Gownes for any money I am like to have.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: We have all played the Lawyers to pretty purpose, in pleading all this while for nothing. Well sir, to avoid further trouble, I am content to withdraw my action, that is, pull off your boots again, and be jogging.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And for my part, sir, I can do no lesse then take you by default and non-suit you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Very good Lawyers both, Is my father quite gone Belt?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Gone in a tempest of high displeasure, sir: And has sent you here all the money he had about him; and bids you refuse it if you dare, 'tis above twice the summe he offered you before; but good sir, do not refuse it. He swears he will try whether you or he shall have his will. Take heed you crosse him not too much.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Well at thy request, because thou shalt not have anger for carrying it back again, I will accept.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I thank you Sir. Consider, he's your father, sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
I do most Reverend Belt. and would be loth to crosse him, although I may as much in taking his money as refusing it, for ought I know, for thou know'st 'tis his custome to crosse me, and the rest
of his children in all we do, to try and urge his obedience; 'tis an odde way: therefore to help my self I seem to covet the things that I hate, and he pulls them from me; and makes shew of loathing the things I covet, and he hurles them doubly at me, as now in this money.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Are you so crafty?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Yes, but do thou put it in his head, and I'le pick out thy braines.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: You never knew an old Serving-man treacherous to his young Master: what? to the hopes o'th' house; you will be heire, that's questionlesse: for to your comfort, your elder brother growes every day more fool then the other. But now the rest of the message is, that you make haste, and come to my Master to the Goat in Covent-Garden, where he dines with his new Landlord to day.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He has taken a house then.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O, a most delicate one, with a curious Belconee and all belonging to't most stately.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: At the Goat does he dine, sayest thou.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: My crew are gone thither too. Pray Mars we fall not foule of one another. Well, go thy way, present my duty to him, I'le follow presentlie. Tell him I took his money with much unwillingnesse.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: As Lawyers do their fees. Let me alone sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Well Tailor and Shoomaker; you have put me to't, but here's your money.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: 'Twas for that we did put you to't Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Let's see your biil Tailor

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.p: Here 'tis, sir, as ready as a Watchmans.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
Then good words will passe it, 7 li. 4. sh. tell your money; yours is 14 sh. boots and Galloshes.
There 'tis and 12. d. to drink.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: I thank your worship.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Are you right Tailor.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.p: Yes and please you Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: There's a shilling for you too, to spend in bread.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: He knows both our diets. We'll make bold to take leave of your worship.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Not so bold as I'm glad I'm too well rid of you, most courteous Gentlemen.

To see what money can do; that can change mens manners, alter their conditions: how tempestuous the slaves were without it. O thou powerful metal! what authority is in thee! Thou art the Key to all mens mouthes. With thee a man may lock up the jawes of an informer, and without thee he cannot the lips of a Lawyer.

div.head: Scoen. II.
div.stage: Enter Crossewill, Rookesbill, Gabriel, Katherine, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Down boy, and bid the Cook hasten dinner.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: What will you please to drink in the mean time, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I will not drink in the mean time, sir, Get you gone.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: A fine old humorous Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Hold up your head, Sirrah, and leave your precise folly. I'll leave you to the wilde world else, dee see. Is the name of a Tavern so odious to you? Ha. Your brother has vext me sufficiently alreadie, and perhaps he'll refuse to come too! If he dares let him. Welcome Mr. Rooksbil, welcom Landlord, and your faire daughter, welcome pretty one. Trust
me a pretty one indeed, pray be acquainted with my daughter there. In your Maiden-company, I hope she will not think the Tavern such a bugs neast as she did. I had much ado to draw my rebellious children to the Tavern after me.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: And truly, sir, 'tis the first to my knowledge that e're my daughter came into.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: All in good time, she may encrease in vertue. But if it be a fault, (as i' my conscience in his thought it is a great transgression) my unsetlednesse, and unprovidednesse else, where or how to entertain a friend, or feed my selfe, may well excuse us all, dee see.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: O Sir, I cannot enough admire that vertue in your sonne.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It is a vice, as much a vice or more, as is your sonnes, your cast-aways as you call him, that sucks no other aire, then that of Tavernes, Tap-houses, Brothels, and such like. I would their extream qualities could meet each other at half-way, and so mingle their superfluities of humour unto a mean betwixt 'hem. It might render them both allowable subjects, where now the one's a firedrake in the aire, and t'other a mandrake in the earth, both mischievous, see how he stands like a mole-catcher. What dirty dogged humour was I in when I got him troe?

sp.speaker: Rookes.
sp.p: Howe're his carriage seems distasteful unto you, I could afford (with your allowance, to make conditions of estate agreeable) to give all that is mine to him with my daughter.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
What a mechanick slave is this, to thank a sonne of mine, howe're I under-rate him, a fit mate to mingle blood with his moore-ditch breed. True, his estate is great, I understand it, but of all foule I love not Moor-hens. Such another motion
would stir me to roare him down the tavernstairs.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: What do you think on't sirs.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Heaven grant me patience.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: Will you consider of it Master Crossewill.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I was never so put to't. I wish we had a stickler. I muse that Master Cockbrayne stayes thus.

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: You do not mind my motion sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Uds precious I minde nothing, I am so crost in mind that I can minde nothing, nor I will minde nothing, dee see. Why comes not Mr. Cockbrayne, Ha!

sp.speaker: Rooks.
sp.p: Yet you minde him it seems. But he, sir, cannot come, and desires you to hold him excus'd. He's gone about some special undertaking, for the good of the Common-wealth, he sayes.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Fart for his undertaking; all the world is bent to crosse me. What is my young Master come? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: My young Master Mr. Mihil will be here presently, he said he would follow me at heeles, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: And why not come before you, sir. Does he not think that I have waited long enough, sir? sure I'll crosse some body under that knaves pate of yours, d'y see.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Thus when any body angers him, I am sure to hear on't.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: So now my spleen is a little palliated, let me speak with you Mr. Rooksbill. Get you down, Sirrah; and bring me word, dinner is not ready, and I'll give you as much more, d'ye see.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: That's his way to his stomach.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And is your brother that your father sayes is so ungracious, so well acquainted with my brother Mihil, say you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh all in all, he's not so familiar with any man, if Mihil Croswill be your brother, as 'tis manifest.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I would not that my father knew it, for all I can expect from him but his blessing, but does your father know it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, I would not he should mistrust it for all he has, blessing and all; and now that I have found you love your brother so well, I will make over my reason and my counsel in trust with you, hoping you will not wrong that trust.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: If I do, may the due price of treachery be my reward.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I love your brother, Lady, and he loves me. The only good act that ever my brother did, was to bring us acquainted, and is indeed all that he has to live on. For I do succour him with many a stolne peece for the felicitie he brought me in your brothers love. Now, my father, whose irreconcileable hate has for ever discarded my brother, should he but dream of their acquaintance, would poison all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But let me ask you, is there an hope betwixt you and my brother ever to come together?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, and a way he has for't, which I understand not yet.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Trust me, I pity you both, your case is very dangerous.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Love's above all adventures, the more hard the atchievement is, the sweeter the reward.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I like her spirit well.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: You Sir, come hither, what is hammering in your head now?
Is't not some Synodical question to put unto the brethren, concerning Whitsonales and Maygames? ha!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surely sir, I was premeditating a fit thanksgiving to be rendred before meat in. Tavernes, according to the present occasion which the time and place administreth, and that as the spirit shall enable me, shall be delivered before you in due season.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I am glad I know your minde; for that trick, my zealous sonne, you shall come in at half-dinner, like a Chafing-dish of coales, when the sawce is cold, to make use of the heat of your spirit; d ye see. I love not meat twice drest.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Good sir, put the Proposition to him, that I made my affection to him, urges it more and more, I never was so taken with a man.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But what's that to your daughter? ha!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: The same affection governes her, she is not mine else.

sp.speaker: Cros
sp.p: Well, hold your peace, and was that your spiritual meditation?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes, verily.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Come Sir, at this Gentlemans request I will now put a question to you concerning the flesh. What, think you of yond Virgin there his daughter? can you affect her so well as to wish her to be your wedded wife?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You mean, elpoused in holy Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Yes, I mean so.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: hum hum hum Psalm tune. How happy.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But do thou say, yes verily to that, and as I hope to have peace in my grave. I'll break the Kings peace on thy pate presently.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is a weighty question, and requires due premeditation in a religious answer, pray give me leave to take advice—

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: What sayes he, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: He sayes he will talk with a cunning man about her.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Sure you mistake him, sir.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: You are welcome, Gentlemen. Will. Harry, Zachary.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Zachary is a good name.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Where are you? he (rings the bell) shew up into the Phoenix. Is the Checque empty?

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Hoyday, here's a din.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: A pottle of Canarie to the Dolphin, score.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Y'are welcome, Gentlemen, take up the lillie-pot.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Half a dozen of clean pipes and a candle for the Elephant. They take their own Tobaccho.

sp.speaker: Vint,
sp.p: Whose room do they foul Sirrah, Harry, Harry?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Do Elephants take Tobaccho?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Carry up a Jordan for the Maidenhead, and a quart of white muskadine for the blew Bore.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Now me thinks, the muskadine for the Maidenhead, and the Jordan for the Bore were better.
Knock aboue, and a pot thrown. Why boyes, drawer, rogues, take up, (below) By and by, by and by, (above) Wine, Tobaccho.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What variety of noises is here? and all excellent ill sounds. (Above) Call up the Fidlers, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Such cries as these went forth before the desolation of the great City.
O prophane tinkling the cymbals of Satan; that tickle the care with vanity, to lift up the mind to lewdnesse. Mine eares shall be that of the Adder against the Song of the Serpent.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: O rare, in a young man!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will roare out aloud to drown your Incantations. Yea, I will set out a throat even as the beast that belloweth.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Most happy youth!

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Hold your peace, Sirrah, or I'le make you bellow for something.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Sfoot-back, Nick to your own room. Thy father's here too, as I breath.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: My Lucie too, as I live. How the devil got they acquainted? Sure he's his Landlord 'Tis so.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Dare you come, sir, you should have stayed now till you had been sent for.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Verily, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Are you at your Verilies too? ha!

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: But for displeasing you, I had rather have graz'd on Littletons Commons, or ha' fasted this fourtnight, then come for my repast into this Wildernesse; but you will ha' it so

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: You are in the right Sir, I'le have it so indeed, I'le know why I shall not else. What do you know no bodie here?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I crie them mercie, my good brother,— and my loving sister.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: But what vertuous men has this man to his sons, and how they thrive in grace against his will, it seems.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: What Gentlewoman is this of your acquaintance, Sister?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis well dissembled brother, but I know your cunning.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Have you betray'd me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mum Mr. Mihil, mum.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: Harry, Harry.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: By and by.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: What devil art thou that roarest in mine eare so.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Hold, I beseech you, I come to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What, with a By and by, that strikes into my head as sharp as a Stellatto.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I come to tell you, sir, that your table's covered in a fairer Room, and more private, your meat is ready to go up, and all in a readinesse.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Now thou art an honest fellow, there's a couple of shillings for thee. Have us out of thy windmil here, I prithee, and thy By and by's.

div.head: Scoen 1.
div.stage: Enter Captain Driblow, Clotpoll, Nick, Anthony, Drawer, A Table, Pot and Glasses.
div.p: GO Sirrah, make your reckoning for our dinner. Leave us this wine, and come when we call you. We have businesse.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I shall, sir, by and by.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, sir, you will be of both you say, the Blade and the Battoon?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Of both, sir, by all meanes, both Philoblathicus and Philobatticus, I. I'le now have all that belongs to your order, or all my money again, that's for a certain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Your money again? loe you there. You bring me a fit man, Gentlemen to be sworn, do you not? that talks of money again, when 'tis a main Article in the Oath, never to look for money again, once disfinger'd.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You will not spoil all now 'tis come so far? will you?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Well sir, when I have my Oath, and that I am sworn one of you. I'le do as you do, and care as little for money as he that has least.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, to the Oath then, for both the Bsade and the Battoon you say?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I by all meanes, Captain, for both. S'lid the Battoon may stick to me, when the Blade may flie out o'th' Hilts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, to the Brokers.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Lay your hands on these Hilts, sir. The Articles that you depose unto are these, To be true and faithful unto the whole Fraternity of the Blade and the Battoon, and to every member thereof.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: As ever faithful member was.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That at no time, wittingly or ignorantly, drunk or sober, you reveal or make discovery of the Brother, or a member of the Brotherhood, of his lodging, haunts, or by-walks, to any Creditor, Officer, Sutler, or such like dangerous or suspitious person.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I defie them all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That if any of the Brotherhood be in restraint or distresse by imprisonment, sicknesse, or whatsoever engagement, you make his case your own, and your purse and your travel his; and that if a brother die or finish his dayes, by end timely or untimelie, by Surfet, Sword, or Law. You wear the sable order of the Riband in remembrance of him.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A convenient cheap way of mourning.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
That your purse and weapon to the utmost
of your strength, be on all occasions drawn to the assistance or defence of a Brother or Brothers friend, be it he, be it she.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I understand you, and shall be as forward to fight for a She-friend, as ever the best man in the mirrour of Knighthood was for an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That you be ever at deadly defiance with all such people, as Protections are directed to in Parliament, and that you watch all occasions to prevent or rescue Gentlemen from the gripes of the Law brissons. That you may thereby endear your selfe into noble society, and drink the juice of the Varlets labours for your officious intrusions.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And that will go down bravely.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You must rank your self so much the better man, by how much the more drink you are able to purchase at others costs.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Cupt.
sp.p: You are to let no man take wall of you, but such as you suppose will either beat you or lend you money.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Better and better still.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The rest of your duties for brevity sake you shall finde specified in that copy of your Order. Kiss the book.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I'le swear to them whatsoever they be.
So, now I am a Blade, and of a better Rowe then those of Tytere tu, or Oatmeal hoe, and so an health to our Fraternity, and in chief to our Noble Captain Driblow.

sp.speaker: Nick. Ant.
sp.p: Agreed, Agreed.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Now are you to practise or exercise your quality on the next you meet that is not of the Brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Are you one of the Brotherhood sir, of the Philoblathici.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I had else lost much sir, I have paid all dues belonging to it.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: So have I as I hope to gain honour by't 40 li. thick at least; yet I have this left, please you command the half sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Another time, your reckoning is not yet paid perhaps.
sp.stage: [Clot. puts his money in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: 'Tis the first money of mine that was refus'd since my coming to Town. I shall save infinitely.
I see now that I am sworn. How would I swear to get by it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Take heed of that, Come hither son.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: How have you screwed this youth up into this humour, that was such a dry miserable Clown but two dayes since.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The old way, by watching of him, and keeping him high-flown a matter of fourty eight houres together.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Men are apt to beleeve strange fancies in their liquour, and to entertain new opinions.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I have fastned three or foure cups upon my precise brother. I would 'twere as many pottles, so it would convert him into the right way of good fellowship.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I would we could see him, to try what good we could do upon him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Perhaps we might convert him.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He's above still with the old men. I stole from him, but to see if your Italick Mystresse were come yet. Your Madam.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, she comes anon; but is my affliction above still.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thy father? yes

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Prithee do not call him my father less he took better courses.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: And so is thy Sister; the little Rogue looks so squeamishly on me, and I on her, as we had never seen before; but the foolish Ape out of a present affection she has taken to my Sister, has discovered to her the whole discourse of our love, and my familiarity with thee, which were enough to spoile all, if it were discovered to the old folkes, before my cards were play'd.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Well, remember Mr. Mihil, you have promised me half, if the old dogged fellow give her all, and you marry her.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Thou canst not doubt me.

sp.speaker: Nick
sp.p: You know I can spoile all when I list, but to shew my countenance in your cause.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Such is your vertue, Sir. Well, I'le up to 'em again before I be mist; and when they part, I am for you again.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I have given you all the rudiments, and my most fatherly advices withal.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And the last is that I should not swear, how make you that good? I thought now I was sworne into this Brotherhood, I might have sworne what, and as much as I would.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That's most unnecessary, for look you son, the best, and even the leudest of my sons do forbear it, not out of conscience, but for very good ends; and in stead of an Oath furnish the mouth with some affected Protestation. As I am honest, it is so. I am no honest man if it be not. Ud take me, if I lie to you. Nev'rgo, nev'r stirre, l vow, and such like.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Or never credit me or let me never be trusted.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: O take heed of that, that may be spoken in so ill an houre, that you may run out of reputation, and never be trusted indeed; the other will gaine you credit, and bring you into good and civil estimation with your Hostesses; and make 'em terme you a faire conditioned Gentleman if he had it; and truly I never heard worse word come out of his mouth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Nev'r-go, nev'r-stir, I vow. I'le have, I vow then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vow, but you shall not, that's mine.

sp.speaker: Clot
sp.p: Cann't you lend it me now and then brother? I'le have, I swear then, and come as nigh swearing as I can.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I swear but you must not, that's mine you know.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest then, I'le have I protest, that's a City-word, and best to cozen with.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Come boyes, fall to some practice, Let me see about at the new French balls, sprung out of the old English vapours

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest come on. I'le make a third man.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Whose man are you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Whose man is not to be asked, nor scarce whose subject, now he is of our Brotherhood.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, by your favour he may ask.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I ask no favour, sir.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: That may be granted.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: You can grant nothing in this kinde.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vow he may grant any thing of any kinde.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I swear, I neither can, nor will grant that.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: That, I protest, may bear exception indeed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Exceptions amongst us? nay, then I vow.—

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I swear.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And I protest—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Part faire my boyes; 'tis very well perform'd; now drink a round to qualifie this bout.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed on all parts.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Look upon me ye Common-wealths men now, like a State-Surgeon, while I search and try
sp.l: The ulcerous coare of foule enormitie.
These are a parcel of those venomous weeds,
That ranklie pester this faire Garden-plot.
Whose boisterous growth is such, that I must use
More policie then strength to reach their root,
And hoist them up at once.
This is my way to get within 'em.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So, 'tis gone round.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I muse these Mumpers come not.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Best send a boy.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Drawer, ha! where be those Rascalls? (Within) By and by.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Are you one of 'em, sir?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I am one that has the favour of the house, sir?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: To intrude into Gentlemens privacies? ha!

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: To seek a poor living and 't please you, by picking up the crums of your liberalitie, for the use of my rare qualities.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And what's your qualitie?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: It is to speak or sing ex tempore upon any Theame, that your fancie or the present occasion shall administer.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Can you drink before you lay your lips to't

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O my weak eye-sight.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Or can you eate a crust without chawing, made of the Flower of Battoon.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O good Gentlemen, forbear, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The flower of Battoon. I protest a good jest, and 'twas mine own before I was aware, for he had the Maidenhead or first-blow of my Battoon. Nay, it shall down.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I will not yet desist; but suffer private affliction with a Romane resolution for the publike welfare, with full assurance that my fortitude shall at last get within 'em.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You are not satisfied, it seems, you Rascal, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Phew! beat not the poor fellow so.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Let me come to him again, and flesh my self upon him. I will not only flesh my self, but tire upon him.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Enough, enough, good Gentlemen, you have beaten me enough of conscience. Was ever good Patriot so rudely handled? but the end crowns all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Forbear him sons. What canst thou be, that canst not be satisfied with beating? speak, art a man or a Ghost?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I have been, Sir, a man, and of my hands, howe're misfortune humbles me under your manhoods. But I have seen the face of warre, and serv'd in the Low-countreys, though I say't, on both sides.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Then 'tis impossible this fellow can be beat out of countenance.

sp.speaker: Mick.
sp.p: We'll leave him in his qualiry for that constant vertue.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sure, 'tis Fenner or his Ghost. He was a riming souldier. Look, do his eyes stand right?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: They had a dish e'ne now, sir.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Of sack, 'tis true here, take another, and wash the inside of your Throat. And let us hear your pipes in their right tune.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Give me a Theam Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The praise of sack. Sing the praise of sack.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let it be of the Blade.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And the Battoon, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Do you call, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, I will have sack.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: T'other quart of Canarie? you shall.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Are your eares so quick? I vow, I'le dull 'em.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Anon, anon.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I say, a song of Sack.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I, let it be of Sack.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Now you pump, do you?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: No, sir, but think of a tune.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: If he can pump us up a spring of Sack, we'll keep him, and break half the Vintners in Town.
sp.stage: (Song. Now B. and Clot. askes Gabriel, Are you a brother. They fall in the burthen.)

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, well-said.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I swear, 'twas well.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest the best that I have heard in this kind. I wonder at his ability. I prithee, art not acquainted with my two Poetical Drury-lane Writers? the Cobler and the Tapster.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: No sir, not I, I work not their way. What I do is ex tempore after the Theme given.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: But they run quite before you. Their Works are in print sometimes. and ready to be sung about streets, of men that are hang'd before they come to the Gallowes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But did not Mihil say he would come again.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I marvel at his stay.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I, and the Mumpers, when come they? I long to see the Sisters, now I am a brother sworn and entred.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O here comes news. How now pig?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: You must all presentlie to the Paris Tavern.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Must? at whose suit!

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Mr. Mihil bade me tell you so.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Is he gone from hence?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: He is, and all his gone and dispersed.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Then the old Jew my father's gone.

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Only there's one delicate demure Gentleman with Mr. Mihil. travell'd along with him towards Paris. I believe he meanes to make a mouth of him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O, 'tis his precise brother. But where's thy Mystresse, and Madama Damaris? that they come not.

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: They desire to meet you there too, 'tis more private.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Away we'll follow thee.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Pig, how does thy father Hog, the Turkie Merchant?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: I am in haste, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why Turkie Merchant?

sp.speaker: Pig.
sp.p: Because he trades in nothing but Turkie commodities; Egges and Concubines; 'twere well to geld him, and send him to the Grand Seignior, to wait in his Seraglio.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Thou hast such a wit in this Clotpoll of thine. The Reckoning Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Here, here, Sir; here's your bill.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let see the summe. What is't Drawer? 40. sh. and 3. d. Si, your dinner, and what you had since, in all, sir.

sp.speaker: Capt,
sp.p: 'Tis very reasonable, Commend me to thy Master. Son Clotpoll pay't. It is your duty.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, for my Brothership.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Boyes, I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: 40. sh. for foure mens dinners, note that, yet he sayes 'tis reasonable.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Good Captain, He was ever the fairest Reckoner, though he has never the luck to pay any thing.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fare you well, father.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: When we have further occasion, we'll repair to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: At Bloomesbury. Father, I know.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Bloomsbury? good, I note it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sirrah, look to the second Article of your Oath.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Against discovery of lodgings, haunts, or by-walks, I am warn'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Look that you be so.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 40. sh. and 3. d. you'l bate the 3. d. will you not?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: We'll not much stand for that Sir, though our Master sits at deare rent.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Give me your two peeces.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray let me see the bill before you pay it.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Well, I can hold it then.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Bread and beer, 1. sh. 4. d. I do not think we four could eat 3. d. of bread, and for my part, I drank but two glasses of beer.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And I but one, I vow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And my father and I but one betwixt us, I protest.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Ha' you no men below?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Below the earth doest mean? I am sure we have none above-ground.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I know not, Gentlemen, there's so much reckon'd at the bar, and you please you may see it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, an't be at the bar, it stands for Law. Well, wine 5 sh. 9. d. I think we had no lesse. A Shoulder of Mutton stuff't with Oysters 8. sh. that cost your Master very near ten groats, a brace of Partridge 5. sh. a couple of Cocks 4. sh. 6. d. a dozen of Larks 20. d. Anchovis 6. sh. I swear but a Sawcer full.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: I'le be sworne they are so much reckon'd in the Kitchen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All's law, I tell you, all's law in Tavernes. But I hope there will be a law for you one o'these dayes. Then is their Fruit and Cheese, Tobaccho, Fire, and I know not what, is't right cast.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: There is more hope of that young man, then of all the rest, indeed it is a sore abuse, another verie weed in the city. I do note that also.

sp.speaker: Nick.
