sp.p: Sirrah, before you have your money, fetch me a glasse of Beere. But canst thou sing this upon any subject.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Any sir, any, an't be till midnight.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: But you have strange helps to your invention. I did note the rolling o' th' eye, and rubbing your Brows sometimes.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: So did I, I protest, and therefore, I tell you what. If he can sing such another Song, and look stedfastly the while upon any thing, and hold his hands behind him. I'le give him half a crown; if not, he shall ha' nothing for tother.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Agreed Gentlemen, give me your Theme.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You shall give it him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And withal, watch him if he stir hand or eye, especially the eye.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I will I protest, and set mine eye against his, that he shall not twink, but I'le perceive it, and lay him o're the pare.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Well Sir, your Theme.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: In praise of the Battoon, and if you misse it you shall be sure on't.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: You'll help me with the burthen, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, yes, for the more grace of the Song.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take you no care for that. Set your eyes and begin.

lg.l: To prove the Battoon the most noble to be.
Of all other weapons observe his degree,
In Field to be Leader of all other Armes,
To conquest and honour, through hazard and harms.
The Gallant and Peasant, the Lord and the Lowne.
Must move by the motion of the Leaders Battoon.
The Pike and the Halbert are subject to it.
The Ensigne, the Partizan, all must submit,
To advance, or retire, fall back, or come on.
As they are directed by the Leaders Battoon.
Then it is to the Souldier the greatest Renown,
To purchase by service to bear the Battoon.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Marry, and take it Sir, why do you stare about? though you have broke Covenant, I have not.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Where be the Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Ha! they are not gone, I hope, where be my brothers Drawer.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Gone sir, and have sent me to you for the reckoning.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest you jest, do you not? I gave 'em the full summe, and all the money I had, I protest, I swear, I vow, now they are not here, I may make bold with their words. They have my money, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: If you have no money, pray leave a pawne, sir.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take him there, put him in a cage, and let him sing it out.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: We know him not, sir.

sp.speaker: Clat.
sp.p: No? he said he had the favour of the house to sing to Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I feare I shall be discovered, sir, I can give your worship credit for a peece till you come to your lodging.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Protest, thou art generous; nay, I know where to finde'em; and thou shalt go with me to 'em, we will not part now, wee'll shoune 'em. I vow, (the words out) here, I'le leave my sword for t'other peece.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Your sword will not serve, sir, I doubt.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Take my coat too, a friend and a Battoon is better then a coat and a sword at all times.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.l: I am glad my feare is over. And after all my sufferings, if at last
Cock braine crow not these roaring Lions down,
Let him be balladed about the Town.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let me now bid you welcome to my fathers house, where till your own be fitted, though my father keep too private a family to expresse large entertainment, yet I hope at worst you shall ha' convenient lodging.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Indeed, I am glad that my father yielded to your fathers friendly request in it; and the more, in regard he is so hard to be entreated to any thing; but especially for your societies sake, sweet Sister. Indeed I'le call you Sister alwayes, and I hope you shall be shortly in my brother Mihils right.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have laid open my heart to you, which indeed is his, but your father, I feare, will never be wonne.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Why you would not have him too, Sister, would you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: His consent I would, and my fathers, I hope, would easily be wrought. You saw he was willing your other brother should have me at the first sight, meerly for his reservednesse, and Mihil methought carried himself as civil to day as he; I mean, as civilly for a Gentleman, that should not look like one fathers of the Dutch Church at five and twenty.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: He was put to't to day. The noise of the Tavern had almost wrought his zeale into fury, it is scarce out of my head yet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But you were about to tell me how he first fell into this veine, this vanity indeed.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I'le tell you now, and in that something worth your observation.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I will observe you.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
My father has an humour, not to like any thing at first, nor accept best courtesies of friends,
though presently he findes 'em most commodious to him; things that he knows not how to be without, and oftentimes desires with the same breath the things he vilified, and scorn'd them the last syllable he spake before. You saw when your father offered him the use of his house here, till his own be furnished, he cried, hah ha! are all the houses in the Town yours Sir; and yet presently entreated for't, and thanked him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That shews the best nature, they say.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: But that is seldome attended by the best fortune. Nay, in us, I mean, his children, he will like nothing, no, not those actions which he himself cannot deny are vertuous; he will crosse us in all we do, as if there were no other way to shew his power over our obedience.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis a strange fatherly care.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Now, note the punishment that followes it. There's not a childe he has, though we all know what we do, that make any conscience of crossing him, we have so much of his good nature in us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And that's as odde a duty in children.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I must confesse it is a stubbornnesse.

Yet for the most part we do nothing, but that which most Parents would allow in their children: and now for my brother Gabriel, with whom I must bring in the story of another Kinswoman of ours, my father had at home with us.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Nay, mark, I pray you, as I would entreat an Auditorie, if I now were a Poet to mark the Plot, and several points of my play, that they might not say when 'tis done, they understood not this or that, or how such a part came in or went out, because they did not observe the passages.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well on, I pray.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
My brother Gabriel, when he was a boy, nay,
till within these two yeares, was the wildest untamed thing that the countrey could possibly hold.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So he is still for ought I know, for I think no man of his Religion in his wits.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I mean in outward conversation, he was the Ring-leader of all the youthful Frie, to Faires, to Wakes, to May-games, footbal-matches, any thing that had but noise and tumult in it; then he was Captain of the young train-band, and exercised the youth of twenty parishes in martial discipline. O he did love to imitate a souldier the best,— and so in every thing, that there was not an handsom maid in an whole County could be quiet for him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He may be good at that sport still, for there is almost none of his sect holds any other game lawful.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Yet did he bear the civillest aud the best ordered affection to our Kinswoman I spake of.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, I remember.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: So loving to her person, so tender of her honour that nothing but too near affinity of blood could have kept them asunder.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And she did love him as well!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: O dearly, vertuously well; but my father fearing what youth in heat of blood might do, removes my brother Gabriel from home into the service of a Reverend Bishop to follow good examples.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But he learned not to be a Puritane there I hope.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p:
You shall hear, Sister, soon after came a Gallant into the countrey from London here, and as we after found, a Citizens sonne, though he shewed like a Lord there. Briefly, he grew acquainted with my brother Mihil. Then woo'd and wonne my
Cousin so secretly, my father never suspected, nor he nor I e're knew whose son he was, nor of what occupation my old lord his father was; but he promis'd her marriage, clap't her, you may guesse where, and so like the slippery Trojan left her.

sp.speaker: Euc.
sp.p: O divellish Rascal!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And foolish creature, she who soon repented it, and with her shame is fled to what part of the world we know not.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: In truth 'tis pitiful, that villain would be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Now upon this, my poor brother that lov'd her so, fell into discontent, forsook his lord, and would have left the Land, but that he was prevented and brought home.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And ever since he has been thus religious.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Thus obstinate, for I think verily he does it but to crosse my father, for sending him out of the way when the mischief was done.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I will not then beleeve 'tis Religion in any of the gang of 'em, but meer wilful affectation. But why, or wherein do you or Mihil. crosse your father.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I tell you Sister we must. He is so crosse himself, that we shall never get any thing of him that we desire, but by desiring the contrary.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why then do you desire him to get you an husband?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Because he should get me none. O Sister, both he and Mr. Cockbrayne, can wish now that I had had his son.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There's another youth now gone on love's pilgrimage, e're since your father crost him in your love not to be heard of.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Hush! the old men.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: In good truth sir, I am taken with your conversation. I like it now exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I'm glad it pleases you.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: 'Tis very faire and friendly, I finde we shall accord.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I am glad I have it for you Sir, I pray, make bold with it.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Then pray sir, let me urge my motion a little further to you.

sp.speaker: Cros,
sp.p: What is't? you cannot utter it so easily as I shall grant it, out with it man.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: That you will be pleased to accept my daughter for either of your sons, your youngest if you please, now I have seen him, I'le give him with her presently, either in hand a thousand pound, and five hundred pound a childe as fast as he can get 'em. And all I shall die seiz'd of.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What a Dogbolt is this to think that I should get a childe for him.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: I hope you do think well on't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray love he does. I hope so too.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I mark his Answer.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I could finde in my heart to ask his good-will my selfe.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And that were a sure way to go without it.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: How say you, sir, is't a match?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I will not stay a minute in thy house, though I lie in the street for't.
Huswife, I'le sort you with fitter companions, Come, follow me quickly.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Heaven blesse me and my childe too from matching with such a disposition.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Truly, sir, I long'd to be out o th' house before.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Before you came in it did you not? ha!

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: These new walls do so stink of the lime methinks.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Marry fough, Gooddie Foyst.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: There can be no healthie dwelling in 'em this twelve-moneth yet.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Are you so tender bodied?

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Even please your selves then where you can like better, and you shall please me.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why you will not thrust me out of your house, will you? ha!

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: There's no such haste, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Indeed there is not, nor will I out for all your haste neither. I'le have look to my bargain.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: With all my heart, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: But no more of your idle motions, if you love your ease in your house, your Inn here.
Here's a letter, sir, from Mr. Cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Is the earer paid, or give him that an't please you.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Some body has anger'd him, and I must suffer.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I sent you to seek my sons, good sir, have you found 'em? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I cannot finde 'em sir. They went out of the Tavern together, they say, and I have been at Mr. Mihils chamber, and there they are not. I went to the Tavern again, and there they were not. Then I beat all the rest o'th' bushes, in this fourest of fooles and mad men, and cannot finde em I, where e're they be.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
Sirrah, go finde em me where e're they be, any where, or no where, finde 'em, and finde 'em
quickly; I'le finde 'em in your Cockscombe else, d' ye see! and bring my sons Sanctity home before it be dark, lest he take up his lodging in a Church-porch; and charge Mr. Mihil that he come not to me till I send for him. Here's danger i'th' house. There was a match-motion indeed.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Good sir, either like my house well, or be pleas'd to please your self with some better.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Pray Sir, be quiet in your house, lest I send you out of it to seek another. Let me see my chamber.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: He must have his way, I see.

div.head: Scoen. 1.
div.stage: Enter Bettie, Frank, with swords drawn make fast the doors.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.l: NAy, you perpetual Pusse, I'le fetch him out of the very bowels of thee.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He never came so deep himself yet with all that he could do, and I scorne the threatning of a She Marmaset.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: (Within) why Bettie, Frank, you mankinde Carions you. I vow, open the door, will you both kill one another, and cozen the Hangman of his fees?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Thou hadst been better have bit off the dugs of thy Damme, thou pin-buttock Jade thou, than have snapt a bit of mine from me.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Here's that shall stay your stomack better then the bit you snarle for. Thou greedy Brach thou.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: (Within) why wenches, are ye wild? break open the doores.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: That I could split that divellish tongue of thine!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I have as good a spight at as ill a member about thee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Hold, what's the devil in ye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Are ye so sharp-set ye Amazonian Trulls?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Let me but make one passe at her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Pray let me go, and let her come.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Can no blunter tooles then these serve to take down your furies?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Let me come but within nailes reach of her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let me but try the strength of my teeth upon her.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: As Hector 'twixt the hosts of Greece and Troy,
When Paris and the Spartane King should end
Their nine yeares warres, held up his brazen lance.
In signal, that both Armies should surcease,
And hear him speak. So let me crave your audience.
Dear Bettie be advis'd, and Frank, forbear
Thy thirst of Sisters blood. Whilest I rip up
The folly of your strife. Your cases both
Have been laid open to me. You contend
For love of a lewd Citizen, that sleights,
Nay more, disdaines, nay more, desies you both.
Tony can tell, Mun Clotpoll also knows
The words he spake, that you were both poor whores,
Not poor alone, but foule infectious harlots.
And that he wears your mark with pain and sorrow,
Hopelesse to claw them off. With constant purpose
Never to see you more, unlesse to greet.
Your bumpin buttocks with revengeful feet.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Did he say so?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And must we two fall out for such a slanderous Villain?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No, agree, agree.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Busse and be friends. Busse, or I'le baste ye both, I vow.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Come Sister we'll be in for ever now.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: For my part, Sister, sure I was not out with you.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: But did he say he would kick us?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lo here, the man that dares it not deny.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: But do ye hear, Gentlemen. I hope you will use me kindlier then so.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Than how, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Then to win all my money, and leave me at stake for the reckoning. Pray do you pay the Drawer for me, though I pay it you again.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What is it Drawer?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: The Gentlewomen and he had 14. sh. in before you came.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 'Tis a plain case, your cloak must answer it at the bar, Sir. Drawer, away with it.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Nay, but Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, do but look after it, till we be gone, and these shall claw thine eyes out.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well sir, I hope this quarter will not be alwayes lawlesse.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Do you grumble? Mr. Cuffelesse.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I vow you shall have cuffes.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Yes, that you shall.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Cuts and slashes too before we part, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You will not murder me, will you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Damosels forbear; and you, forbear your noise. I vow, I'le slit your wistle else. You shall give him due correction civilly, and we will make him take it civilly. Sit you down Sir.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: What will you do with me?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, mum.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O, are ye here! was it a brotherly trick do ye think, to leave me to pay one reckoning twice? or did I think never to be made a mouth more, after I had paid my swearing dinner, and am I now a greater mouth then e're I was?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Mum, hold your tongue still in your mouth, lest I halifax it with your teeth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Halifax my tongue. And listen to a businesse.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Do yon know this man?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Yes, the City mouth we had tother night.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: These are the Sisters that his lavish tongue so lewdly did deprave.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I cry them heartily mercy Are you of the sweet Sisterhood? I hope to know you all, all the pretty Mumpers in the berrie here, before I have done. 'Tis true, I protest, he spake words of you, that such flesh and blood could not bear. He could not have spoken worse of mutton of a groat a quarter.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: And were we so fond to fight for him?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But now we'll both be revenged upon the flesh of him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pray let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, they shall beat you first. And mark me well. Do thou but stir an hand or foot, or raise a voice that may be heard to the next room, well cut thy weasand. Now wenches take your course.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Nay, you slave, we'll mark you for a Sheep-biter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We'll teach you how to scandalize.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Have I given you that you cannot claw off, you Mungrel.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Rare, I protest.

sp.speaker: Ciot.
sp.p: — oh— oh— oh.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: There, there.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We'll claw thine eares off rather.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: — oh— oh— oh.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: O brave.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O out-rage, most insufferable, all this goes into my black book.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: To him Bettie, at him Frank; there whores, there.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fie, fie, forbear, enough, too much in conscience.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: That young man has some pity yet.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I swear you shall no more.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Alas, good Gentlemen, it is enough.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, do you prate? you shall have as much. Come, take the Chaire, Sir, the breeches shall bait him too.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O good Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, they shall. To him and claw him, I'le clapperclaw your sides else

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O me! what mean you?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Heyday! his beard comes off.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And his head too What rotten scab is this?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I protest, they have pulled my pieced brother in pieces here.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, some disguiz'd villain, and but for doing the State so good service, we would hang him presently without examination.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I know him. And you shall not touch him. Best is, he knows nor me. Good Heaven, what Braintrick has possest him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, what canst thou be?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, 'tis an honest fellow, that is only asham'd to run so base a course for his living in his own face. Poor man, I warrant his feare threatens his breeches shrewdly. But let's away, and quickly, our stay is dangerous. Come, we forgot Mich Croswil and the wenches.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Come all away then, Sirrah, thank this Gentleman, and pray for him at the end of your Songs hereafter.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Farewel, friend Peece. I'le know you better now, before you have't again.
sp.stage: Ex. omnes but Cock. and Cit.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What monsters in mankinde? what hell-hounds are they? only as Ovid feign'd among the Getes. A friend at need, I with a friend was blest, Whom I may gratifie, and plague the rest. How is it with you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: O, I am very sore.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Indeed you are sorely handled. This may warne you out of such caterwaling company. You look like one more civil. And in hope you will be so, I'le bring you to a Barber.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Alas, my Cloke.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: I'le help you to that too, so you with me, Will in an honest plot Assistant be.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: O Sir, in any thing, and thank you too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: A Paris ill ya ben veni- Here's no bush at this door, but good wine rides post upon't, I mean, the sign-post. Boy, get you down, and if Nick Rooksbill, or any of his company ask for me, bring 'em up, d'ye hear.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will, I will, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: You are welcome to Paris brother Gabriel.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is neverthelesse a Tavern, brother Mihil, and you promised and covenanted with me at the last house of noise and noisomnesse, that you would not lead me to any more Tavernes.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Lead you brother? men use to be led from Tavernes sometimes. You saw I did not lead you nor bring you to any that was more a Tavern then the last, nor so much neither; for here is no Bush you saw.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: 'Twas that betrayed and entrapped me: but let us yet forsake it.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray let us drink first brother. By your leave here's to you.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: One glasse-full more is the most that I can bear. My head is very full, and laboureth with that I have had already.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: There Sir, I'le undertake one good fellow, that has but just as much Religion as will serve an honest mans turne, will bear more wine then ten of these giddy-braind Puritanes, their heads are so full of whimseys.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: 'Tis mighty headie, mighty headie, and truly I cannot but think that the over much abuse of these out-landish liquors, have bred so many errours in the Romish Church.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Indeed brother, there is too much abuse made of such good creatures. Wine in it self is good, you will grant, though the excesse be nought; and Tavernes are not contemptible, so the company be good.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It is most true, we finde that holy men have gone to Tavernes, and made good use of 'em upon their Peregrinations.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p:
And cannot men be content to take now and
then a cup, and discourse of good things by the way. As thus. Brother, here's a remembrance (if she be living, and have not lost her honour) to our Cousin Dore as.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O that kinswoman of ours. She was the dearest losse that e're fell from our house.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Pledge her, good brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I do—

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: I hope 'twill maudlenize him.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: But have you never seen that miscreant that wrong'd her, since he did that same, they say you knew him.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Alas, suppose I had, what could be done? she's lost we see. What good could she receive by any course against him.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: It had been good to have humbled him, though into the knowledge of his Transgression. And of himself for his soules good, either by course of Law, or else in case of necessity, where the Law promiseth no releefe, by your own right hand you might have smote him, smote him with great force, yea, smote him unto the earth, until he had prayed that the evil might be taken from him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: This is their way of loving enemies, to bear 'em into goodnesse. Well, brother, I may meet with him again, and then I know what to do. If he knew him as I do now, what a religious combate were here like to be at Nicks coming.
Sir, here's a Gentlewoman asks for Mr. Rooksbill.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: The travell'd Gallant, is't not.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes sir, and the old black party, her Land lady with her. But they ask for no body but him, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Say he is here by all meanes, and bring 'em up.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Women! pray brother lets avoid the place, let us flie it. What should we do with women in a Tavern?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: No harme assure your selfe, cannot we govern ourselves?
sp.stage: Enter Dorcas and Madge, and start back.

sp.speaker: Nay,
sp.p: Lady, stay, he will be here presently, that you look for.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will not glance an eye toward temptation.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I am amaz'd sure, I have seen this face, howe're your habit and the course of time may give't another seeming.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Good Angels, help my thoughts and memory. It is my Kinsman Mihil. What's the other that hides his face, so?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Do you turn away?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: It is my Cousin Gabriel, strangely altered.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Come hither you. I'le make a little bold with you. Thou that hast been a concealer of more sins in womens actions, then thou hast grizled hairs.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Sure I will speak to him, he alwayes lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Reveale a truth to me on my demand, now instanrly, without premeditation. I'le cut thy tongue out else.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What's here to do? do you think I am a devil? that you make such conjurations over me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I think thou art as true a servant of his as any Bawd can be. But he now if thou darest. How long have you known that Gentlewoman? and what do you know by her?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Here's a stirre about nothing. I know nothing by her, not I. Nor whether she has any thing or nothing, that a woman should have by the report of knowledge of man, woman or beast, not I. She came to me but this morning, with a purpose to set me up in my new house as I hoped. But she has taken a course to make it honestly spoken of already, to my utter undoing, but she never comes within my doors again, as I hope to thrive by my Trade hereafter.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Pray look upon me, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Was she so resolutely bent, and so soon altered?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Upon the very first fight of the very first man that came into my house, the very first houre of my setting up in it.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: What man was that?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: A shame take him, your roaring friend, Nick. I think she is enamoured of him, or of something she guesses he has; and would faine play the honest woman with him, that never played honest man with woman in his life.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: 'Tis she, and 'tis most wonderful.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: If you knew who I were, you would not be so strange to me.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And here she comes me a hunting after him, like a fondling, whilest halfe a dozen peeces might ha' been gotten at home by this time, aud she have had the halfes of it in her purse by this time; if she would have done, as I thought, she would have done by this time.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Alas, poor Howlet.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: I sent whooping after the best guest that haunt my house, to have taken the first fruits of her conversation, and she would not see a man of 'em, to my undoing.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well leave thy hooting, Madge, and hold thy peace. thou shalt get by it.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Yes, I shall get a good name shortly, and this geare hold, and turn begger, I shall.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pray sir, but one word.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Speak to her, brother, 'tis our Cousin Dorcas.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Will you abuse me too? is she not lost?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And will not you give her leave to be found again? his wine and her sudden apprehension works on him at once. Cousin, I'le speak to you, though I confesse the miracle of our meeting thus amazes me.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: O Cousins both. As ye are Gentlemen, and of that noble stock, whose meer remembrance, when he was given up, and at the brink of desperate folly, stroke that reverend fear into my soul, that hath preserv'd my honour from further falling. Lend me now your aide, to vindicate that honour by that man, that threw me in the way of losse and ruine.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: All shall be well, good Cousin, you shall have both hands and hearts to re-estate you in him. So that in fact you have not wrong'd that honour, since he forsook you.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: On my soule I have not.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Infants then shall be pardoned. Brother speak.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: You were wont still to be my loving'st Cousin.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What a strange dream has wine wrought in my head.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.l: I hope it will work out his superfluous zeale.
And render him civil Christian again.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It is no dream, good Cousin, you are awake,
And I, that Dorcas, for whom you have wish't

Affinity of blood might be dispens'd with. And you
to be my choice. So well you lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And will above my life affect you still. But you must leave these gauds and prophane dressings.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Bawds did he say? how comes he to know me troe?

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.l: How came my Cousin Gabriel thus translated.
Out of gay cloathes long haire, and lofty spirit,
Stout and brave action, manly carriage;
Into so strict a Reformation?
Where is the martial humour he was wont so to affect.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: His purity and your disgrace fell on you both about a time, I faith.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Do you swear by your FAITH?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: He's falling back again.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Some more wine. You will drink with our
Cousin, brother, will you not?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What wine is't, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes, in a cup of sincere love.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: What other wine you please, Gentlemen, we have none such i'th 'house.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Of the same we had, sir.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Call not for wine for us, Cousin.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Assuredly, we are no prophane wine-bibbers, not we.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Modest, and well-spoken verily, she should be a Sister or a Matron.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we'll all drink for the good o'th' house.
'Tis upon putting down, they say, and more o'th neighbours. But Cousin, he knew you not to day.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, nor dreams of me.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And the old one knowes nothing, does she.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: No, by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: She can bewray nothing then. My brother knows not him. I only do for his faire Sisters sake, of which you may hear more hereafter; in the mean, bear your selfe faire and free, as if you knew him not, and I'le work him to your end, never fear it.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: You are a noble Spokesman.
sp.stage: [Bawd and Gabriel confer devoutly the while.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Truly, you speak most edifyingly.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well-said, give it to my brother. Drink to our Cousin, Brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will, and to that vertuous Matron, whose care of her, I hope, tends unto good edification.— Truly the wine is good, and I was something thirsty.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Best drink again then, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will follow your motherly advice.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: 'Twill work, anon, I hope.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And you have travell'd Cousin. I may suppose you brought this well-disposed Gentlewoman from Amsterdam with you. And this unto your welcome, hoping I shall be informed by you how the two zealous brethren thrive there? that broke in St. Hellens.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Of that or any thing sir, pray drink again, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You Jade you, hold your tongue.
sp.stage: Enter Nick, Anthony, Clotpoll, Bettie, Frank.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: O, are ye here Gallants! I made all the haste I could, but was stayed, I vow, by the bravest sport, baiting of a fellow or two with our Pusse-cats here. I could e'ne find in my heart to marry 'em both for their valours.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Those words are daggers.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I pray dissemble your passion.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: What? are you acquainted already?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.p: Did not I tell thee she was a brave Madona?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: How long have you had acquaintance with her, Nick?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Never saw her before this morning, I, standing upon her Belconee.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Truly Cousin, I think 'twas you that I saw to day too, standing upon a Bellconee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: You spell very modestly, sir. Your brother
I take it. But did you call her Cousin, sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yes sir, she is my Cousin.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: 'Twill out too soon. Why Nick, thou knowest these kinde of creatures call and are called Cousins commonly.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, in their tribe. But I thought he had been too holy for them. But Dammy—

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O fearfully prophane!

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You said you had a storie to relate, of dire misfortune. and of unquoth hearing. I come to hear your story, what stop you your eares at? sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I dare not speak it but in thy reproof. Thou swearest Gee uh Dee, dee arm thee, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow thou liest, I call'd her Dammy, because her name is Damyris,

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I say thou liest, her name is Dorcas, which was the name of an holy woman.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Shall we have things and things? I vow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And I protest.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: This will spoil all. Brother, I pray forbear.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I may not forbear, I am moved for to smite him; yea, with often stripes to smite him; my zealous wrath is kindled, and he shall flie before me.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: Let me entreat you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bet. Frank.
sp.p: What furie's this?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Great Damboys shrink, and give a little ground.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will pursue him in mine indignation.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O me!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And beat him into Potsheards.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Now he has bang'd the Pitcher, he may do any thing.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray, brother, be perswaded.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: A brother to be so controuled?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You sir, put up your Steel-stick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I desire but to know first, if he be a brother.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes marry is he, sir.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Sir, I am satisfied. So let him live.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Pray give me leave to ask you, do these men take part with the brethren?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, and are brothers a little disguiz'd, but for some ends.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Some State-occasions.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Meer Intelligencers, to collect up such and such observations, for a great Separatist that is now writing a book against playing at Barlibreak, moulding of Cocklebread, and such like prophane exercises.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Truly such exercises are prophane exercises, that bear the denomination of good things ordained for mans use, as Barley, Cockles, and Bread are such things to be made sports and play-games? I pray you let me see these brethren again, to make my atonement with them. And are those Sisters too, that were with them?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
O, most notorious ones, and are as equally disguiz'd to be as rank Spies as the other. S'lid man, and they should be taken for such as they are, they would be cut off presently. They came in this
mad humour to be merry with you for my sake.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Pray let 'em come again, I shall not be well until I have rendred satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You must do as they do then, or they will think you are a Spie upon them.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will be as merry as they, let wine be given unto us.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: More wine, Boy, and bid 'em all come in.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Alas, Cousin, let him drink no more.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Cousin, it shall be for his good and yours, as I will order it.
sp.stage: Enter Nick. Anthonie, Clotpoll, Bettie, Frank, Drawer with wine

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: All welcome, not any repetition, but begin a new

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I will begin it, two glasses: it shall be a faithful Salutation to all the Brothers and Sisters of—

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The Blade and the Scabberd.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: It shall go round.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'le swear you do not well to let him drink so.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well said civil Roarer.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Let it go round, go to, you are a wag. I know what you mean by the Blade and the Scabberd.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Who could have thought this had been such a brother.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Nay, who could have thought you had been of the brethren.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Brethren sir, we are the Brothers.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Yea, the disguiz'd ones.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: How? disguiz'd ones?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
Do not crosse him again. If thou doest, and I do not maul thee. Yes, brother, these are vertuous
men howe're they seeeme.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, I have so much vertue as to rebuke thee for lying. But we are brethren, sir, and as factious as you, though we differ in the Grounds; for you, sir, defie Orders, and so do we; you of the Church, we of the Civil Magistrate; many of us speak i'th' nose, as you do; you out of humility of spirit, we by the wantonnesse of the flesh; now in devotion we go beyond you, for you will not kneel to a ghostly father, and we do to a carnal Mystresse.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le stop your mouth, you said you came to be merry.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Yes, I vow, and brought Fidlers along, but they must play i'th' next room, for here's one breaks all the Fiddles that come in his reach. Come fir, will you drink, dance, and do as we do?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I'le drink, I'le dance, I'le kisse, or do any thing, any living thing with any of you that is Brother or Sister. Sweet-heart let me feel thy Coney.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.l: I now he's in. Play Fidlers. Dance.
All bravely performed, admirably well done, &c.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, thou art a brother after my own heart.

sp.speaker: Women.
sp.p: We cannot commend you enough, sir.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: This done in civil fort among our selves, I hope, will prove no scandal to a brother.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: 'Twill prove an honour to our faction.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I thirst to do it honour.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Give him some wine, he thirsts.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Thou little dapper thing, thou, hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou seest he can scarce stand.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: No, my religious brethren, no more wine.
Enough's a feast, and little doth suffice.
sp.p:
I thirst to do some honour to our cause. To lead
forth legions to fight a battel 'gainst our. malignant adversaries.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Brave.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Such an employment now would make me famous, for my sufficiency of Att in Armes.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, this man has hidden things in him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He has as brave a warlike spirit, man, before his precise humour tainted it, as ever breath'd in Hector.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow then, a good orderly diet of nothing but sack for a week together, would revive it in him, and bring it to good again.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I hope, 'tis done already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How do you, sit?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I feare some Jesuitical fumes have invaded my Brain pan. All me thinks goes whirley, whirley, whirley.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Best lie down upon a bed. Drawer!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Souldiers must not be curious. A Bench or any thing.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: The Gentleman may have a bed here, an't please you. But sir, there's an old angry Gentleman below, that asks for you, and by all description for that mortified Gentleman. And will by all meanes presse into your room here.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: It is my father.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: O me! What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Mad. Bet. Fran.
sp.p: We shall be all clap't up.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Fear nothing, veile your face a little; Who is with him?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: No body but his old Servingman, that it seems discover'd you. You may put this Gentleman into this inner room, and keep the Key your selfe. I know not what charge he has about him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Admirable honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: And you may tell your father he is gone, for he is gone you see.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow. a wit.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Now if you'll be civil, I may bring him up to you, if not, because he is your father, we'll thrust him out of doors, an't please you.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Notable rascal, well sir, let him up. I know how to fit him.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: But this delays my businesse, Cousin, and will, I fear, frustrate my hopes.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Nor hinder any thing, I'le warrant thee, he's thine. Play Fidlers, t'other dance.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Will you! protest.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You are not wilde?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Come Wenches, if he venture in his fathers sight, shame take us and we blush.

sp.speaker: Cross. Belt.
sp.p: And I had not sold all my land to live upon my money in Town here, out of danger or the Statute, I would give thee a Copihold for this discovery.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I thank your worship, and truly 'tis a goodly sight, me thinks, an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I'm glad it likes you. Heigh, excellent good again. Heigh, Heigh, what an happinesse may fathers boast, that can bring their children up to this. (Dance ended )I cry ye mercy, Gentlemen all. Ha! I am sory I interrupted your serious private occasions.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Would you speak with any here, sir?

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: It is my father, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Thy father? hold thy peace; dar'st thou use thy father thus? to spend thy time thus! ha! Is this place fit for the son of a Gentleman of quality? ha! why doest not answer me, does this company sort with thy reputation? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Sir, the company.—

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Hold thy peace, I say, or are these exercises allowable for a Gentleman, that ever said or heard Grace at his fathers Table? answer me that.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: An't please you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Hold thy peace when I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: The company, sir, offends not you, I hope; you see the worst of us.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: In good time, sir, you are the distracted Gentlemen, I take it, that ask't him if he would moot to night? Is this your mooting? do you put cases to your Wenches, or they to you?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow thy father talkes too much.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Which are the better Lawyers? ha!

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: But that you are his father, sit, and an old man, and he an honest young Gentleman, and our friend, we would tell you.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I thank you for him, yes truly, heartily; and for your good opinion of him, heartily. Pray keep him amongst you while ye have him, for I'le ha' no more to say to him, I. Is your Invectives against drinking, wenching, and the abomination of the times come to this? is this your spending of time more pretious then money? is it you that knows not what to do with money but to buy books; and were drawn with such unwillingnesse to a Tavern? ha! you shall graze upon Littletons Commons, or eat nothing but books, an't please you, for any exhibition thou ever get'st from me— And in that faith thou hast lost a father. Come sir, you have brought me to a goodly sight here; would any Villain but thy selfe have shewed his Master light to see so much woe! Thy Coxscombe shall yet pay for't.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O sir, O.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: This was your trim sight, was it?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: But well remembred. Pray where's your brother? my son I would say; for I know no brother or father thou hast. Where is Gabriel?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He is not here, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Did you not tell me, Sirrah, he was here?

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I told you then too much. I feel it here.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: He was here, sir, but he is gone, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: So, so, he's lost. He must be cried, or we shall never finde him.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le warrant you, I'le find him yet to night, sir. Pray Gentlemen pay you the Reckoning, I'le wait upon my father home.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Was that spoke like a son of mine? must others pay your reckoning, and I in place; take that, and do not make me mad. And why should you home with me? I pray, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Because sir, it grows dark, and 'tis the worst way as it is about the town; so many odde holes a man may slip into; pray take me with you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Pray take no care for me, sir, and let the way be as it is. Do not think me worse at it in the dark then your self, I beseech you. But you talk't of the Reckoning, pray let not the want of money for that hinder the search of your brother. There's towards your paines for that; and so for a farewel to you and your friends here, till I hear thou keepest better company, let me hear no more of thee.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: There was no way to get this money, and be rid of him, but to offer him my service He would have driven me out before him else. But come, let's see my brother that went to sleep in so warlike a Passion. I hope he'll wake in a better.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Mun Clotpoll, thou art dull.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: No, I protest, but struck with admiration at the old Blades humour.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Come, Dammy and the rest, be merry. I vow, we'll sup together, and so at last hear all thy dismal story.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.l: I mean he shall, and such an Audit make,
As shall restore her honour from the stake.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p:
WHat has this Coxscombe Cockbrayne writ me here? That he desires his absence be excus'd. What have I to do with him? when I send for him, let him come to me. That he is upon a point of discovery in a most excellent project for the weeding of this Garden? what Garden? what project? A project he says here for the good of the Republike, Repudding. This fellow has in stead of braines, a Cob-web in his Noddle, with little strawes, feathers, and wings of dead Butterflies hanging in it, that having motion by his aery fancie, there dance and keep a Racket; 'tis to teach women silence, or some such foolish impossibility. He is ambitious to be call'd into authority by notice taken of some special service he is able to do the tate aforehand. But what great service he is able to do it, or which way to undertake it, falls not in the reach of my imagination. But good Mr. Croswill, by your favour now, what reason have you to slight or wrangle at this man? this honest Cockbrayne? that has alwayes been a constant friend to you, and officious in many good wayes, and is a Gentleman, not only of good descent and estate, but of a good disposition. And you two, Mr. Crossewill, by your leave, have alwayes agreed like
neighbours children. I, the divel was in't, and now he vexes me again; we agreed in one point so well, that we have undone a couple of our children by it, and hindred the getting of I know not how many more. His son and my daughter should have married. And on a sndden he and I both consented to a dislike of the match and broke it, and have both repented it an hundred times since. We agree very wel in that point; and now is his son irrecoverably lost, and my daughter resolutely bent to be an Ape-leader in Limbo. But what's all this to the affliction I suffer in my sons now? that one of them from a riotous boy. should grow into a Puritanical Woodcock; and the tother from a civil well-qualified fellow, turn'd absolute Ruffian. There, there, I there's the devil in't. I could beat my selfe for getting such children.
See, see, my Master for want of other company fallen out with himself, and it please you, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: It does not please me, nor thou pleasest me, nor any thing pleases me. The world's bent to crosse me, and thou shalt feel it.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: O good sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Is it not so, sir, was not that dunce Gabriel, a most notorious wilde thing

Before he steer'd a Religious course? but then he run so full a saile, that he pass'd and was beyond the line of Religion before he was aware; and as he passed it under the torrid Zone of Zeale, the Calenture took him o'the pate, that he is mad with it, and as far beyond Religion now as it is to it.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Sir, there's hope that he may he fetch't halfe way back again, by your fatherly advicement, and become a sound man.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: And then was not Mihil so civil, that he made me even sick to see him. And now is he flowen out as far into rior t'other way.

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: But he, sir, will appear a present comfort to you, he is reclaim'd already; you shall never see such a Reformation in a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What's this you tell me? ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: He has cast off his long-curl'd haire and all.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.l: He had been better have cut his head off.
Where is he!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: Below sir, and a Gentlewoman with him, but very much afraid to appear to you. I never saw a man so timoursome.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Do you think it fit I should go down to him, or he come up to me, fir, ha!

sp.speaker: Belt.
sp.p: I'le fetch him, here's a life!

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I charg'd he should not come at this house too, for feare he might be catch'd with this mechanick fellows daughter, though her portion be around one. And let him take heed he look not at her.
Blesse me! what changeling is this? he's in his Brothers cut.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Sir,— Sir.—

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Would you speak with any here, sir, do you know me. I know not you, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: The sense of your late displeasure, sir, has so humbled me into the knowledge of my self, that on the wings of true obedience, I flew after you to make a childes submission at your feet, to crave your pardon for my riotous transgression, and to ask your blessing.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
A delicate speech, pray take it for fashion-sake.
But if I know how to look towards thee.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray sir, bestow it really upon me.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: God blesse thee, I say, and so much many honest men bestow daily on sons that are none of their own, if thou beest mine, how camest thou thus like a fellow that had narrowly scap't the Pillorie, and brag'd in the publication of his eares? not an hair left to hide them.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: To shew my readinesse to reform my life, sir. And yet a willingnesse withal to live, as well, as civilly, in which I am in all humility to preferre a suit to you. You know, sir, I am but a younger brother.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What will this come to?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Here is a widow, sir, a Gentlewoman of great estate, and of a well-known life. Antient she is, and has had husbands. How many?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Foure truly, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Foure sir, I would not lie. Of which the worst spoke well of her on's death-bed.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: What's that to me or thee? come to the point.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I have all wo'd and wonne her, sir, and crave but your good-will to marry her. I have brought a Church-man and a Kinsman to give her.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Why so, what needs two words then? do you think I can deny you?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: If he does grant it, 'tis the first request that e're he granted in his life. Sure the old Match-maker the devil thinks I am in earnest to marry this beast. And puts a readinesse in his hand to forward it.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Widow, you are welcome. Why call you not your Priest? or tarry sir, let me question you but a little, Do you think seriously you love this widow?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Better then many men love their wives, I am perswaded.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, what children have you widow?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Never had any, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Very well still.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Nor ever like to have any, fir, that's the comfort. We shall live at the lesse charge.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Thou art a covetous and a preposterous Knave. Wouldest thou bury up thy youth in barren ground? doest seek after wealth, and not after issue? doest love to feed on other mens leavings? or travel only in a beaten path? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: A man goes certainest on his journey so, sir, and lesse trouble it is you know to go in at a great gate, then a narrow wicket.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: You have said enough, sir, and delight to crosse me; but I'le crosse you for once, and lay a crosse upon you, shall perhaps carry you to your grave. Go, fetch your Priest.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le face it as far as I dare. I hope I shall have the grace to pull my hand from the book when it comes so far.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Widow, you are resolv'd to have him too.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Before all men i'th' world by your fair leave, 1.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: You shall not have him.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Without your free consent, I will not.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I am resolv'd I'le do't. And 'twill be the best crosse trick that e're I did in my life. Pray let me speak in some more private with you.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: If I but 'scape Bridewell, I care not.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p:
Now Tonie, she's thine own, Now Sister Kate;
he's thine. The Priest has pronounc't it. I say, Amen to't. And heaven give you joy.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Now you have done the best brotherly office that ever made a Sister happy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And the friendliest to a friend. We have been casting for it, Sweet, this Twelve-moneth, and Heaven pardon me. I vow'd never to take acquaintance of my Father, till 'twere effected. Although I know of late he has been willing.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: And so is mine, I know, but yet he swore, that I should match my self before he knew't, or I should never marry.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You'll finde him of another minde towards me, and force me into wedlock presently.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: You have ta'ne the likeliest course that could be. But what is your disguiz'd woman, Brother.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: What you shall never know, Sister, I hope.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Come sir, I have broken off the match with your widow; and she's content to leave you as she found you. And now take me this pretty, simpring, plump-lip't, ruddie-cheek't, white-neck't, long-finger'd Virgin in hand, or I will swindge you, Sirrah, look to't. If you cannot live civilly with a young wife, you cannot but be mad with an old, I think. Besides, she's a friends daughter of mine, and prepar'd by her discreet father here to love you. Come, and kisse her, quickly, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I cannot do't for all the wealth in the world.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Kisse a Maid I never saw above twice in my life.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: He will have me think him a bastard, do I what I can. Canst thou see a Maid twice, and not kisse her?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, twenty times, sir, and not kisse her, or if once, not above, sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: But you shall kisse her above and below, sir, and in every room o'th' house, sir, before you part. Stand faire pretty one.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I know not how to do't.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: You were not best let me instruct you. I can be angry too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: His back side's towards me.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Turne your self, Sirrah, or I'le turne you. Go to, bend your body a little and be hang'd. So, now come your way, and say after your little Sir John here, I Mihil take thee, Lucie, &c. As learning shall enable him to proceed without book.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Pray let'em do it in the next chamber, they are too bashful afore us. There are witnesses enough. Go all in, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Widow, will you give me leave to obey my father?

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: With all my heart, and say Amen to the marriage.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I think I shall have my will at last upon one of my rebellious off-spring.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: And now, pray give me leave sir, to let you know how happy I do hold my selfe in this marriage. I did like this Son better then the other before. And now I like him better then I did at my former view of him, by some Reformation that I do observe in him. And I do not a little rejoyce in the honour I may have to call you brother.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p:
That very word brother out of his mouth, has turn'd my stomack. I must pull all in pieces again. And yet let me see these young bloods when they
are set on't; if they do not marry, they will do worse. Let em e'ne go on now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: You may easily conceive, sir, what a comfort it will be unto me, that I now growing old, and having (I give praise for't,) wealth enough, and no childe that I make account of but this one daughter, may, before I die, see Grandchildren that I may have by her sufficiently provided for, be they more or lesse in number, they may have enough.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: There he is again, he calls my Grand-children that shall be, his Grand-children. Am I a Gentleman, and can hear this? if it be not too late, I'le spoile the getting of your Grand-children.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Heaven give you joy. Heaven give you joy.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: What, are you married?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I do pronounce them man and wife.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Mad. Kat. And we are witnesses.

sp.speaker: Crosse.
sp.p: What remedy?

sp.speaker: Mih. Luc.
sp.p: We are, and crave your blessings.

sp.speaker: Cross. Rook.
sp.p: All blessings be upon you, (all salute).

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: But you, sir, Mr. Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le only gratifie the Minister.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Do so, and pay him well, it is, perhaps, for the dearest fault that e're thou didst.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: There's for your paines, sir. Madge, there's for you. Enough to purchase thee a Licence to sell Ale, Tobaccho, and Strong-water again in Godpiece-Rowe, for here will be no dwelling for thee, I see that.

Now, brother Anthonie, go you all back to the company we left, and see that my Instructions be followed
concerning my brother Gabriel, Nick, and his Dammie,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: All, all.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: Shall he go from me?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, but you shall follow him presently, trust to me Sister. Go, take no leave of 'em. I'le bring 'em upon you presently.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Are you at leisure now, sir, to tell me of your brother.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, to my grief, sir, praying you may have patience.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: To your grief, sir, he is not dead then? Younger brothers seldome grieve for their Elders death.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray bear it as you may, sir I left him in an heavy plight. And let me speak it with sorrow, he lay speechlesse.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Alack-a day, good Gentleman, my son in-law, perhaps, is heire already.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: And hast thou been here all this while fooling or wiving (all's a matter) & left thy brother in danger? ha!

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: He's well attended, sir, and look't unto. Nor would I wish you see his weak estate.
It can but grieve you, sir, my wife and sister, together with my self, will go. Or if
It please my father Rooksbill here, because his power in this quarter is available.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Go, shew the way. I'le go in person, I. My son's my son.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Nay, pray sir.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Yes, 'cause you have a wife, you shall controul me. Will you go on, sir.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Well, I'le bring you to him, sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What was your widow, sir, she stunk of Aqua-vitae, fearfully.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: I'le tell thee as we go. Kisse.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: What a drunken sot was I, that knew thee not all this while? I vow, thy story pities me. I'le marry thee, and turne thee to thy friends, for I am sure I have none that will keep thee for my sake.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: I ask no further satisfaction of you, then to be honested by marriage. I'le work for a poor living.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Prithee Mun seek me a Priest.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: I have no acquaintance in their function, I.

sp.speaker: Dorc.
sp.p: My Cousin Mihil said he would bring or send one.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: There's no starting, that Mihil has a fist over me. I vow, and thou wert not his Kinswoman, thou should to the Common yet.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Father, how come you hither?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Did not the company send for me?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, not we.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The City-mouth, that peck't us at my lodging last night, came to me with an abominable scratch't face, and warn'd me on a businesse hither.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I smell some trick.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Some treacherie upon the brotherhood, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Timorous thing! what in our own Quarter?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: If you doubt any thing, 'tis best remove.
The fellow was sorely handled.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I would but see the carcass of authority prance in our Quarter, and we not cut his legs off. Welcome Tonie, what hast thou brought the word here to passe for the Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, you must make a wedding-night on't Nick, Mihil will go no lesse.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: My Vow is pass'd, and before you, sir, I confirm it. This is my wife. Anon, you shall perform the holy Ceremony,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Tis well, pray sir, retire your self to the next room there a while, and stay you with him, Lady.
But what do you with Gabriel? Is it not time to wake him yet?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: 'Tis now upon the point, h'as slept two houres.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Father, you'll see a brave experiment upon a Gentleman that has been a youth.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: And of the Philoblathici, as we are now.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: And since was grown one of the reformed, and we are now in practice to retrive, and bring him back to his first condition.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Have you followed all Mihils directions?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Hitherto we have. First, you saw he was laid defunct in Sack, next in his sleep, we have accoutred him in martial abiliments, and now we mean to wake him with alarmes shall affright the silly humour out of him, and render him his warlike faculty, or our Art failes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Where be the Wenches?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The Sisters of the Scabberd, there's the sport on't. They have their parts to play upon him too. But for his drink now when he wakes, you said you would have a bottle of the womans what do you call't yonder? the Medea.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What? the charm'd liquor that Medea brew'd to make old father Aeson young again?
Must that renew his youthful spirit in him?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: No, Sack will do better. When he wakes he will be very dry, then a quart-draught of good Canarie will so screw him up. 'Tis time 'twere now in practice. So, softly, softly. We must but halfe wake him at first.
sp.stage: A Bed put forth, Gabriel on it, Bettie and Frank.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: O some small drink.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Here, drink it off, sir, (Drinks )Drum and Trumpet. An Alarm.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Surpriz'd by th' enemie, whilest we have plaid the Sluggard in our Tents.

sp.speaker: Capt. Nick. Clot.
sp.p: Hold Captain, hold, we are your souldiers.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Y'are Mutineers, and have disturb'd my rest. And I'le do Martial Justice on you all.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: I vow, hold, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Know you not discipline? or are you growen rebellious in the Camp. I'le teach you warfare.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You have conjur'd a fury into him to beat us into fitters.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: My pate bleeds for't; I protest.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I'le make you know command.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Noble Commander, hold thy furious hand, and heare thy souldiers speak.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What have we women for our Martial Musick?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: None but the She-Trumpet, a neighbour here, and her Sister, that was Drum-mayor to my Countrey-Amazons, that pull'd up the Inclosures to lie all in Common.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Is the enemy i'th' field?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Upon their march, Captain, and we your officers: But rows'd you up to be in readinesse.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
You are my Lieutenant, you my Ancient, and you two my Sergeants; and you must know the Commander
you serve under, to be none of those Letter-carriers that know not so much as the termes of discipline, what a Flanker is, Nor a Raveling is. Nor a Petarre is. Nor a Curtain is. Nor a Bulwark is. Nor a Bastile is. Nor a Counterscarp is. Nor a Casemate is. A Gabion is: Nor any left word of fortification. How can such fresh-water Captains command?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Right noble Colonel. He shall be our Colonel.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: One souldier made up of Sack, is worth as many as would drink a fresh water river dry.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I knew, men of abilities should at last be put in action.
sp.l: Valiant men and wise,
Are only fit for weighty enterprise.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: O noble Colonel.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What would an upstart Militaster now, That knew no rudiments of discipline, nor Art of warre, do in a sudden service? or say, when I know how to have my Ordnance planted here, my Cavalrie mounted here, my Battery-discoverer on such a point, my Trenches cut thus, my Mine carried thus, my Gabions rais'd thus. Here my Parapet, there my Pallisadoe o'th' top of that. The enemie made saltable six hundred paces there. And I draw out my Musketeers to flank 'em in their Trenches here, while my Pikes and Targeteers advance to the breach there. What would Captain, my Lords man, or Sergeant-major, my Ladies Kinsman, sent in by honourable favour, do or say in such an expedition?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Braver and braver still.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: This goes beyond the Blade and the Battoon.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p:
Or how would their braines lie in their breeches, when the able Captain leads up his men in the Head of a Troop bravely, charges with his shot,
makes a stand with his Pikes, does execution with his Sword, the Cannon playing, the Drum beating, the Shot thumping, the Ensignes waving, the Armes clashing, the Aire rending, Dust and Smoke clouding, Blood raining. And then to bring up such a Division to fight, make good such a Ground, relieve such a Squadron, fetch off such a losse, r'enforce the Ranks that are broken. March on, Come off. Beat the Bessognes that lie hid in the Carriages. O the renowned life of a worthy Commander.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Sound Drum and Trumpet.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: A Colonel, a Colonel.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Whither hast thou brought me? does thy brother lie speechlesse in this house? ha! what in the name of tumult can these be?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Pray sit, attend, you will be pleased anon.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: A still march now. So, I have lost a great many of my men. But courage yet, you poor remainder of my scatter'd Troops. Stand. Qni vala. An Ambuscado of the enemy. Alarme. Lieutenant, charge in with your Shot. Now Gentlemen, for the honour of Covent-Garden, make a stand with your Pikes; in to the short sword; well fought, take Prisoners. Sound a Retreat now. Faire, faire i'th' coming off. So, 'twas bravely perform'd.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Must we not fall to rifling now, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Part faire on all sides, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: What's this, a vision, sure I do aile something.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Is't possible it is thou? art thou run mad as far as hell the tother way now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.l: My wicked, caitiffe, reprobate son is here too.
Pray let me flee, I am but a dead man else.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: You shall receive no harm, sir Lay by your Armes my Masters. I bring none but friends.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Thou canst not make that good, my father's there.

sp.speaker: Mih
sp.p: I'le make him friends with thee. Go and dispatch within.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'le see it done, and take our new made Brides with us for witnesses.

sp.speaker: Rook
sp.p: Has his shame yet taught him to shunne my sight.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: And shall returne him instantly your comfort.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Unpossible, unpossible.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Attend the event.

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: I rather thought I should have found you, sir, disputing with the Pastors, and the Elders; yet to say truth, this is the better madnesse. What can this mean? how came he thus translated? what Charmes, or what Inchantments are upon him?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.l: What Babel was a building in my braines?
But now it turnes, and I can recollect
The knowledge of a father, brother, Sister.
And that a thousand vain imaginations,
Like scatterings of light things upon the earth,
Rushes, loose leaves, sprigs, straws, and dust
Contracted by a whirlwinde, were blowen up,
And lodg'd in the rich Seat of Contemplation,
Usurping there the room of vertuous thoughts.
Honour awake me from this Lethargie.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What can those women that appear like furies be in this action?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: They were but us'd as properties to give new motion to his mortified condition.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p:
I know not what to say to any thing; there
is some Spell upon me too. My anger has forsook me. What are those men that bear a countenance. As if they stood indifferently affected to Bedlam and Bride-well.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Meaning by us, sir. If our sight offend you,
Know we are men that dare forbear the place.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: I son, let's go, our stay is dangerous.
They look like Peace-maintainers, we'll fall off.

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: O tarry, Gentlemen, we are all undone else. If you make not your peace before you stir, both you and I must suffer.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: The Magistrates and Officers with their Bill-men have ta'ne us by surprise. They are i'th' house.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: O me! the blew Gown Colledge.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Wheels and whips. I feel what we must go to. Did not I say our stay was dangerous?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Did not I say there was some subtile practice upon the Philoblatici? and that we were betrayed hither?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: There's no escaping forth. And Gentlemen, It will but breed more scandal on my house, and the whole plantation here, if now you make rebellious uproar. Yield your weapons, and welcome Justice but like subjects new, and peace will follow.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: But where's Nick? where's Tonie?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: They shall yield up their weapons. So do you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes yes, 'tis best.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Shall we, sir, shall we?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes sir, you shall.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p:
So, sir, I will then, not the Blade alone. But
for your more security, the Battoon, There see my Armes forth coming.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Say they shall have faire welcom, What are they married?
sp.stage: Enter Nick. Dorcas, Ant. Kat. Luc.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, as fast as troth and holy words can binde 'em.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.l: 'Tis well. Now sir, let me entreat your favour.
'Tis my first suit to you since I was your son,
That before others entrances distract our troubled
Scoene, these may be reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Even unto the earth, sir, and humbled with as true a penitence, as son can be for wronging of a father, I beg your pardon and blessing.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Give it him, Brother Rooksbill, I dare say 'twill make him a good man.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: Heaven make him so. My blessing and my prayers shall not be wanting.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: What? my Neece Dorcas made an honest woman?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Was that the man that wrong'd my Cousin Dorcas?

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: Yes, and has now made ample recompence.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Here they are altogether, sir.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p:
Lay hands on all. First, on that old Ruffian, the Incendiarie, that sets the youthful bloods on fire here with his Infernal discipline. Next, take his sons, there's one, that young Blade there, Have I now got within ye, Gentlemen? will you have Songs ex tempore? know ye me now? a ha! I'le be call'd the
Weeder of this Garden. Take up those She weeds there. I have the rank one here. I took her stragling in my Round e'ne now.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: My Tenant, I take it, Mrs. Margerie Howlet.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Your widow sir, I think.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: But for a shift sir, now you know my aim.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: O good your worship, as you came of a woman.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Peace Circes, cease thy charmes. What cluster have we here now. O here's another of the sons of noise.

sp.speaker: Rook.
sp.p: That's my son now, sir, by your leave, and I'le baile him.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: What Mr. Rooksbil, are you here? what woman's this?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: My Neece, sir, his sons wife. And I'le baile her.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What Mr. Croswill, you among this Ginge too?
How will you 'scape commitment?

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Cockbrayne? how his braines crow now?

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Who's here? your daughters too? but what are these?

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I hope they'l prove my sons, and be indifferent men in time, sir, by that time their haire may grow, or be reduc't to an indifferent length.

sp.speaker: Mih.
sp.p: That's done on me already, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Now he looks as like a Rogue as e're he did again.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And sir, for me, now that my Cousin is restored, and the wilde fury of my wine abated.
I do you the obedience of a son, acknowledging my former formal habit was more of stubbornnesse then true devotion. For which I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: There's more deceit under these half Foot-balls, then in whole Pudding-bags. Well boyes, be you indifferent sons, neither too hot nor too cold. I have found a fault in myself, I confesse. I will reform it, and be an indifferent father.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O here's the man I sought, whom, I confess, I am half sorry to commit with the rest, because I found him civiller.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hoping you will not stake that good opinion, I'le now come nearer to you. And since here is such a convention of love and joy. I hope my offering of a sons true duty may finde I.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: What? my son Antonie?

sp.speaker: Cross.
sp.p: How? how? your son that should have had my daughter? Come hither Kate, now if thou lov'st him, take him. Are you content, friend Cockbrayne.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: O sir, most happily.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Why run you not together?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is too late, or needlesse now for me to marry her.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Is't come to that? and if I do not swindge him—. Are you too good, sir, for my daughter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I do not say so, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Huswife, do you like him?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: No more then he does me, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Get you together, or I'le swaddle you both into one, you perverse fooles.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sir, the truth is, we are married already.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: 'Tis so, indeed, sir.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: Heyday! who am I trow? how durst you do it without my consent?

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.p: I had your consent, sir, you commanded me to take my choice in whom I pleas'd, before you would take notice.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: I cannot abide this wrangling. Give you joy.

sp.speaker: Cock.
sp.p: Joy and my blessing on you. Why I know not whom to commit now.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: You have done the Common-wealth a special piece of service the while with your State-braines. But let us make a night of this, I pray.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sir, the parties have given me satisfaction, and I am content they be releas'd.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.p: There's an honest fellow now, and looks like one that would be beaten every day for ready money. Go now, while ye are well, and be seen no more in this Precinct.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Never and't please your worships, never.

sp.speaker: Cros.
sp.l: 'Twas built for no such vermine. Hence away.
And may the place be purg'd so every day.
'Tis no unworthy member may be found,
To pester or to vilifie this ground.
That as it was intended, it may be
A Scoene for Vertue and Nobilitie.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: TIs not the Poets Art, nor all that we
By life of Action can present on't, ye
Can or ought make us to presume a Play
Is good, 'tis you approve't. Which that you may
It cannot misbecome us, since our gaines
Come by your favour, more then all our paines.
Thus to submit us unto your commands.
And humbly ask the favour at your hands.

div.head: Another.
div.l: 'Tis done. And now that Poets can divine,
Observe with what Nobility doth shine
Faire Covent-Garden. And as that improves,
May we finde like Improvement in your Loves.
